Many of the active Hyperloop routes being planned currently are outside of the U.S. [[Hyperloop One]] published the world's first detailed [[business case]] for a {{convert|500|km|mi||order=flip|abbr=out|adj=mid|-2}} route between [[Helsinki]] and [[Stockholm]], which would tunnel under the [[Baltic Sea]] to connect the two capitals in under 30 minutes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hyperloop One, FS Links And KPMG Publish World's First Study Of Full Scale Hyperloop System|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/hyperloop-one-fs-links-and-kpmg-publish-worlds-first-study-of-full-scale-hyperloop-system-300294040.html|publisher=PR Newswire|date=July 5, 2016}}</ref> Hyperloop One is also well underway on a feasibility study with [[DP World]] to move containers from its [[Port of Jebel Ali]] in [[Dubai]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hyperloop One gets $50 million in funding led by Dubai's DP World Group, one of the world's largest ports operators |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-hyperloop-one-dubai-20161013-snap-story.html|access-date=November 26, 2016 |publisher=LA Times|date=October 12, 2016}}</ref> Hyperloop One on November 8, 2016, announced a new feasibility study with Dubai's Roads and Transport Authority for passenger and freight routes connecting Dubai with the greater [[United Arab Emirates]]. Hyperloop One is also working on passenger routes in [[Moscow]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.rt.com/business/343569-russian-railways-hyperloop-technology |title=0 to 400mph in 2 seconds? Russian Railways eyes supersonic Hyperloop technology |work=RT |date=May 19, 2016 |access-date=June 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://deutsche-wirtschafts-nachrichten.de/2016/06/02/russland-plant-hyperloop-strecke-zwischen-moskau-und-sankt-petersburg |title=Russland plant Hyperloop-Strecke zwischen Moskau und Sankt Petersburg |work=Deutsche Wirtschafts Nachrichten |date=June 2, 2016 |access-date=June 3, 2016}}</ref> and a cargo Hyperloop to connect [[Hunchun]] in north-eastern China to the [[Port of Zarubino]], near [[Vladivostok]] and the [[North Korea]]n border on Russia's Far East.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hyperloop One Can Open Up Russia's Far East to China Trade | Hyperloop One|url=https://hyperloop-one.com/blog/hyperloop-one-can-open-russias-far-east-china-trade|website=Hyperloop One|access-date=November 26, 2016}}</ref> In May 2016, Hyperloop One kicked off their Global Challenge with a call for comprehensive proposals of hyperloop networks around the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hyperloop One Global Challenge|url=https://hyperloop-one.com/global-challenge|website=Hyperloop One|accessdate=October 11, 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, Hyperloop One selected 10 routes from 35 of the strongest proposals: [[Toronto]]–[[Montreal]], [[Cheyenne, Wyoming|Cheyenne]]–[[Denver]]–[[Pueblo, Colorado|Pueblo]], [[Miami]]–[[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Dallas]]–[[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]]–[[Houston]], [[Chicago]]–[[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]]–[[Pittsburgh]], [[Mexico City]]–[[Guadalajara]], [[Edinburgh]]–[[London]], [[Glasgow]]–[[Liverpool]], [[Bengaluru]]–[[Chennai]], and [[Mumbai]]–[[Chennai]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Todd |first1=Jeff |title=Hyperloop Becomes Closer To Reality In Colorado |url=http://denver.cbslocal.com/2017/09/14/hyperloop-travel-cdot/ |accessdate=September 15, 2017|publisher=CBS4 |date=September 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hyperloop One Global Challenge Winners|url=https://hyperloop-one.com/global-challenge-winners/|website=Hyperloop One|accessdate=October 11, 2017}}</ref>
Others have put forward European routes, including a [[Paris]] to [[Amsterdam]] route proposed by Delft Hyperloop.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://tweakers.net/reviews/4327/3/tu-delft-onthult-hyperloop-ontwerp-het-ontwerp-van-de-tu-delft.html |title=TU Delft onthult Hyperloop-ontwerp - Vervoermiddel van de toekomst |trans-title=TU Delft unveils Hyperloop design - Means of transport of the future |work=Tweakers.net |language=nl |first=Olaf |last=van Miltenburg |date=January 23, 2016 |access-date=January 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eP8Bz_XCIrk |title=Delft Hyperloop - Revealing the Future of Transportation |website=YouTube.com |date=January 22, 2016 |access-date=January 26, 2016}}</ref> A [[Warsaw University of Technology]] team is evaluating potential routes from [[Cracow]] to [[Gdańsk]] across [[Poland]] proposed by Hyper Poland.<ref name=itkey20160217>{{cite news |last=Wedziuk |first=Emilia |url=https://itkey.media/hyperloop-made-in-poland-gets-more-and-more-realistic |title=Hyperloop made in Poland gets more and more realistic |language=Polish |work=ITkey Media |date=February 17, 2016 |access-date=February 24, 2016}}</ref>
[[TransPod]] is exploring the possibility of Hyperloop routes which would connect [[Toronto]] and [[Montreal]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/day6/episode-303-charlie-sykes-on-nevertrump-predicting-the-polaris-climate-change-cities-plus-lots-more-1.3764152/toronto-to-montreal-in-less-than-30-minutes-how-a-canadian-company-plans-to-make-it-happen-1.3764201 |title=Toronto to Montreal in less than 30 minutes? How a Canadian company plans to make it happen |first=Brent |last=Bambury |work=[[CBC Radio]] |location=Canada |date=September 16, 2016 |access-date=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Rapid Transit">{{cite news|title=Rapid Transit|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/rapid-transit-1.4296028|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=CBC|publisher=CBC|date=September 18, 2017}}</ref> Toronto to [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]],<ref name="Daily Hive">{{cite news|last1=Aboelsaud|first1=Yasmin|title=Toronto tech company proposes Toronto-Windsor hyperloop connection|url=http://dailyhive.com/toronto/transpod-hyperloop-study-toronto-windsor-2017|accessdate=October 4, 2017|publisher=Daily Hive|date=July 26, 2017}}</ref> and [[Calgary]] to [[Edmonton]].<ref name="cbccalgarycorridor">{{cite news|title=Calgary to Edmonton in 30 minutes? Hyperloop could be the future of transportation in Alberta|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/calgary/transpod-hyperloop-calgary-edmonton-corridor-1.4060954|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=CBC|publisher=CBC|date=April 7, 2017}}</ref> Toronto and Montreal, the largest cities in Canada, are currently connected by [[Ontario Highway 401]], the busiest highway in North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oppositelock.kinja.com/the-busiest-highway-in-north-america-1559577839 |title=The Busiest Highway in North America |work=Opposite Lock |location=US |date=April 6, 2014 |access-date=November 7, 2016}}</ref>
[[Hyperloop Transportation Technologies]] (HTT) reportedly signed an agreement with the government of Slovakia in March 2016 to perform impact studies, with potential links between [[Bratislava]], [[Vienna]], and [[Budapest]], but there have been no developments on that since.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/federicoguerrini/2016/03/10/hyperloops-first-european-route-to-be-built-on-the-bratislava-budapest-route |title=Crowdsourced Hyperloop Venture Inks A Deal With... Bratislava? |first=Federico |last=Guerrini |work=Forbes |date=March 10, 2016 |access-date=March 12, 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, HTT signed an agreement to explore the route [[Bratislava]]—[[Brno]]—[[Prague]] in [[Central Europe]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/18/hyperloop-transportation-technologies-plans-to-connect-all-of-europe-starting-with-the-czech-republic/ |title=Hyperloop Transportation Technologies plans to connect all of Europe, starting with the Czech Republic |first=Sarah |last=Buhr |work=TechCrunch |location=US |date=January 18, 2017 |access-date=January 23, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, [[SINTEF]], the largest independent research organization in Scandinavia, announced they are considering building a test lab for Hyperloop in Norway.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.dn.no/nyheter/2017/12/18/0648/Havbruk/sintef-vil-teste-hyperloop-for-laks |title=Sintef vil teste hyperloop for laks |work=www.dn.no |access-date=January 23, 2018 |language=no}}</ref>
===Open-source design evolution=== In September 2013, [[Ansys]] Corporation ran [[computational fluid dynamics]] simulations to model the aerodynamics of the capsule and [[shear stress]] forces that the capsule would be subjected to. The simulation showed that the capsule design would need to be significantly reshaped to avoid creating [[supersonic]] airflow, and that the gap between the tube wall and capsule would need to be larger. Ansys employee Sandeep Sovani said the simulation showed that Hyperloop has challenges but that he is convinced it is feasible.<ref name="Discovery"/><ref name="CNet"/>
In October 2013, the development team of the [[OpenMDAO]] software framework released an unfinished, conceptual open-source model of parts of the Hyperloop's propulsion system. The team asserted that the model demonstrated the concept's feasibility, although the tube would need to be {{convert|4|m|order=flip}} in diameter,<ref name="openmdao"/> significantly larger than originally projected. However, the team's model is not a true working model of the propulsion system, as it did not account for a wide range of technological factors required to physically construct a Hyperloop based on Musk's concept, and in particular had no significant estimations of component weight.<ref name="github-mdao"/>
In November 2013, [[MathWorks]] analyzed the proposal's suggested route and concluded that the route was mainly feasible. The analysis focused on the [[g-force|acceleration]] experienced by passengers and the necessary deviations from public roads in order to keep the accelerations reasonable; it did highlight that maintaining a trajectory along I-580 east of San Francisco at the planned speeds was not possible without significant deviation into heavily populated areas.<ref name="mathworks20131122"/>
In January 2015, a paper based on the NASA [[OpenMDAO]] open-source model reiterated the need for a larger diameter tube and a reduced cruise speed closer to Mach 0.85. It recommended removing on-board heat exchangers based on thermal models of the interactions between the compressor cycle, tube, and ambient environment. The compression cycle would only contribute 5% of the heat added to the tube, with 95% of the heat attributed to radiation and convection into the tube. The weight and volume penalty of on-board heat exchangers would not be worth the minor benefit, and regardless the steady-state temperature in the tube would only reach {{convert|30|-|40|F-change|C-change}} above ambient temperature.<ref name="Chin2015"/>
According to Musk, various aspects of the Hyperloop have technology applications to other Musk interests, including [[surface transportation on Mars]] and [[Musk electric jet|electric jet propulsion]].<ref name=fortune20160131>{{cite news |last=Morris |first=David Z. |url=http://fortune.com/2016/01/31/mit-wins-hyperloop-competition-and-elon-musk-drops-in |title=MIT Wins Hyperloop Competition, And Elon Musk Drops In |work=Fortune |date=January 31, 2016 |access-date=February 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name=musk20160130>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ab2VVp1GfmA|title=Elon Musk speaks at the Hyperloop Pod Award Ceremony|publisher=YouTube.com|first=Elon|last=Musk|date=January 30, 2016|access-date=June 3, 2016}}</ref>
Researchers associated with MIT's department of Aeronautics and Astronautics published research in June 2017 that verified the challenge of [[aerodynamic]] design near the [[Kantrowitz limit]] that had been theorized in the original SpaceX Alpha-design concept released in 2013.<ref>{{cite conference |url=http://hyperloop.mit.edu/uploads/7/6/1/8/76180385/opgenoordcaplan_2017_aerodynamics_hyperloop_online.pdf |title=On the Aerodynamic Design of the Hyperloop Concept |first1=Max M. J. |last1=Opgenoord |first2=Philip C. |last2=Caplan |conference=35th AIAA Applied Aerodynamics Conference |publisher=[[AIAA]] |location=US |doi=10.2514/6.2017-3740 |date=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Richard Geddes (academic)|Dr. Richard Geddes]] and others formed the Hyperloop Advanced Research Partnership to act as a clearinghouse of Hyperloop public domain reports and data.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Egli|first1=Dane|title=Hyperloop will improve transportation and national security|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/opinion/oped/bs-ed-0801-hyperloop-elon-musk-20170728-story.html|accessdate=August 26, 2017|publisher=Baltimore Sun|date=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
===Mars=== According to Musk, Hyperloop would be useful on Mars as no tubes would be needed because Mars' atmosphere is about 1% the density of the Earth's at sea level.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.universetoday.com/22603/mars-compared-to-earth/ |title=Mars Compared to Earth |last=Williams |first=Matt |date=July 3, 2017 |website=Universe Today |access-date=September 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="youtube20160131"/><ref name="conversation20150713">{{cite web |url=https://theconversation.com/elon-musks-high-speed-hyperloop-train-makes-more-sense-for-mars-than-california-43686 |title=Elon Musk's high-speed Hyperloop train makes more sense for Mars than California |work=The Conversation |first=Leon |last=Vanstone |date=July 13, 2015 |access-date=February 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.techinsider.io/elon-musk-talks-hyperloop-on-mars-2016-2 |title=Elon Musk talks Hyperloop on Mars |first=Danielle |last=Muoio |work=Tech Insider |date=February 6, 2016 |access-date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> For the Hyperloop concept to work on Earth, low-pressure tubes are required to reduce air resistance. However, if they were to be built on Mars, the lower air resistance would allow a Hyperloop to be created with no tube, only a track.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.universetoday.com/127356/hyperloop-on-mars |title=Musk Says Hyperloop Could Work On Mars... Maybe Even Better! |first=Matt |last=Williams |website=Universe Today |date=February 12, 2016 |access-date=February 26, 2016}}</ref>
==Hyperloop companies==
{{Anchor|Hyperloop One|Hyperloop Technologies}}
===Virgin Hyperloop One=== {{Main|Virgin Hyperloop One}} Virgin Hyperloop One (formerly Hyperloop One, and before that, Hyperloop Technologies)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/story/virgin-hyperloop-one-engineering|title=Deep in the Desert, Richard Branson Is Bringing the Hyperloop to Life|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://time.com/4325633/hyperloop-one/ |title=The Race to Build the Hyperloop Just Got Real |first1=Alex |last1=Fitzpatrick |newspaper=Time Magazine |location=United States |date=May 10, 2016 |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> was incorporated in 2014 and has built a team of 280+,{{when|date=July 2018}} including engineers, technicians, welders, and machinists. It has raised more than {{US$|160 million}} in capital from investors including [[DP World]], [[Sherpa Capital]], [[Formation 8]], 137 Ventures, Caspian Venture Capital, Fast Digital, GE Ventures, and [[SNCF]].{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
Hyperloop One was founded by [[Shervin Pishevar]] and Brogan BamBrogan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hyperloop Is Real: Meet The Startups Selling Supersonic Travel |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bruceupbin/2015/02/11/hyperloop-is-real-meet-the-startups-selling-supersonic-travel/#953f0ff76867 |website=forbes.com |publisher=Forbes |access-date=July 18, 2017}}</ref> BamBrogan left the company in July 2016,<ref>{{cite news |title=Ousted Hyperloop One co-founder Brogan BamBrogan is suing Shervin Pishevar, claims harrassment [sic] |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/07/12/ousted-hyperloop-one-co-founder-brogan-bambrogan-is-suing-shervin-pishevar-claims-harrassment/ |website=Techcrunch |publisher=Techcrunch |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> along with three of the other founding members of [[Arrivo]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Arrivo arrives as a new Hyperloop venture from a Hyperloop One co-founder |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/09/arrivo-arrives-as-a-new-hyperloop-venture-from-a-hyperloop-one-co-founder/ |website=Techcrunch |publisher=Techcrunch |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> Hyperloop One then selected Josh Giegel, a former SpaceX engineer, to be a co-founder.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hyperloop One Replaces Co-Founder Brogan BamBrogan with Senior Vice President of Engineering Josh Giegel |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/hyperloop-one-replaces-co-founder-brogan-bambrogan-with-vice-president-of-engineering-josh-giegel-1467403686 |website=wsj.com |publisher=Wall Street Journal |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref>
Hyperloop One has a 75,000-square foot Innovation Campus in downtown LA and a 100,000-square foot machine and tooling shop in North Las Vegas. By 2017, it had completed a 500m Development Loop (DevLoop) in North Las Vegas, Nevada.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/28747-hyperloop-one-devloop-nevada-test-track|publisher=Inverse|date=March 7, 2017 |title=Photos: Hyperloop One Shows Off 'DevLoop' Test Tube in Nevada}}</ref>
On May 11, 2016, Hyperloop One conducted the first live trial of Hyperloop technology, demonstrating that its custom linear electric motor could propel a sled from 0 to 110 miles an hour in just over one second.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://digg.com/2016/hyperloop-one-test-video-elon-musk |title=Watch The First Real-World Test Of Hyperloop Technology |first=Dan |last=Fallon |work=Digg |location=US |date=May 11, 2016 |access-date=May 12, 2016}}</ref> The [[g-force|acceleration]] exerted approximately 2.5 g on the sled. The sled was stopped at the end of the test by hitting a pile of sand at the end of the track, because the test was not intended to test braking components.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3585662/It-works-Elon-Musk-s-super-fast-Hyperloop-successfully-demonstrated-Las-Vegas.html |title=Elon Musk's Hyperloop is successfully demonstrated in Las Vegas |first1=Ellie |last1=Zolfagharifard |first2=Richard |last2=Gray |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=Australia |date=May 12, 2016 |access-date=December 30, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, Hyperloop One released a preliminary study that suggested a Hyperloop connection between [[Helsinki]] and [[Stockholm]] would be feasible, reducing the travel time between the cities to half an hour. The construction costs were estimated by Hyperloop One to be around {{euro|19 billion}} ({{US$|21 billion}} at 2016 exchange rates).<ref name=helsinki-verge>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/5/12099612/hyperloop-one-helsinki-stockholm-30-minutes-study |title=Hyperloop One says it can connect Helsinki to Stockholm in under 30 minutes |last1=Hawkins |first1=Andrew J. |work=The Verge |location=US |access-date=July 6, 2016 |date=July 5, 2016}}</ref>
In August 2016, Hyperloop One announced a deal with the world's third largest ports operator, DP World, to develop a cargo offloader system at DP World's flagship port of Jebel Ali in Dubai.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/hyperloop-one-dp-world-sign-agreement-to-pursue-a-hyperloop-route-in-dubai-300313889.html |title=Hyperloop One, DP World Sign Agreement To Pursue A Hyperloop Route In Dubai}}</ref> Hyperloop One also broke ground on DevLoop, its full-scale Hyperloop test track.
In November 2016, Hyperloop One disclosed that it has established a high-level working group relationship with the governments of Finland and the Netherlands to study the viability of building Hyperloop proof of operations centers in those countries. Hyperloop One also has a feasibility study underway with Dubai's Roads and Transport Authority for passenger systems in the UAE.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kharpal |first1=Arjun |title=Hyperloop One explores setting up high-speed transport system in Finland, Netherlands, Dubai |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/10/hyperloop-one-finland-netherlands-dubai-setting-up-high-speed-transport-system.html |work=CNBC |access-date=November 11, 2016 |date=November 10, 2016}}</ref> Other feasibility studies are underway in Russia, Los Angeles, and the Netherlands.
In May 12, 2017, Hyperloop One performed its first full-scale Hyperloop test, becoming the first company in the world to test a full-scale Hyperloop.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/story/hyperloop-one-test-success/|work=Wired |date=July 12, 2017 |title=Hyperloop's first real test is a whooshing success}}</ref> The system-wide test integrated Hyperloop components including vacuum, propulsion, levitation, sled, control systems, tube, and structures.
On July 12, 2017, the company revealed images of its first generation pod prototype, which will be used at the DevLoop test site in Nevada to test aerodynamics.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.curbed.com/2017/7/12/15960522/hyperloop-one-pod-design-test |first=Alissa |last=Walker |work=Curbed |date=July 12, 2017 |title=Hyperloop One reveals full-size prototype of its shiny new pod design}}</ref>
On October 12, 2017, the company received a "significant investment" from the Virgin Group founder Richard Branson, leading to a rebrand of the name.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/introducing-virgin-hyperloop-one-worlds-most-revolutionary-train-service |title=Introducing Virgin Hyperloop One – the world's most revolutionary train service |last=Branson |first=Richard |date=October 12, 2017 |publisher=Virgin |access-date=October 12, 2017}}</ref>
In February 2018, Richard Branson of Virgin Hyperloop One announced that he had a preliminary agreement with the [[Maharashtra]] State government to build the Mumbai-Pune Hyperloop.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/indyventure/virgin-hyperloop-india-pune-mumbai-fast-shuttle-train-maharashtra-richard-branson-narendra-modi-a8217511.html |title=Virgin to build super-fast Hyperloop shuttle between Pune and Mumbai as India ramps up infrastructure spending |first=Joe |last=Sommerlad |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=February 19, 2018 |access-date=February 21, 2018}}</ref>
===Hyperloop Transportation Technologies=== {{Main|Hyperloop Transportation Technologies}} [[Hyperloop Transportation Technologies]] (HTT) was a group of more than 800 engineers{{when|date=July 2018}} and professionals located around the world. Some collaborate part-time; others are full-time employees and contributors. Some members are full-time paid employees; others work in exchange for salary and [[stock option]]s.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
HTT announced in May 2015 that a deal had been finalized with landowners to build a {{convert|5|mi|km|0|adj=on}} test track along a stretch of road near [[Interstate 5 in California|Interstate 5]] between Los Angeles and San Francisco.<ref name="fortune20150520">{{cite news |url=http://fortune.com/2015/05/20/elon-musk-hyperloop-test-track-california/ |title=Elon Musk's craziest project is coming closer to reality |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |first=Daniel |last=Roberts |date=May 20, 2015 |access-date=June 2, 2015}}</ref> In December 2016, Hyperloop Transportation Technologies and the government of [[Abu Dhabi]] announced plans to conduct a feasibility study on a Hyperloop link between the [[UAE]] capital and [[Al Ain]], reducing travel time between Abu Dhabi and Al Ain to just under 10-minutes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Abu Dhabi explores Hyperloop link with Al Ain, potentially transforming cruise tourism in the city|url=http://www.cruisearabiaonline.com/middle-east-cruise-news/2016/12/12/Abu-Dhabi-explores-Hyperloop-link-with-Al-Ain--potentially-transforming-cruise-tourism-in-city|publisher=Cruise Arabia & Africa|date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> In September 2017, HTT announced and signed an agreement with the [[Andhra Pradesh]] government to build a track from [[Amaravathi]] to [[Vijayawada]] in a [[public-private partnership]], and suggested that the more than one hour trip could be reduced to 5 minutes through the project.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/first-hyperloop-in-india-to-be-launched-between-amravati-and-vijayawada/articleshow/60395340.cms |title=First Hyperloop in India to be launched between Amravati and Vijayawada |work=The Times of India |author=Satyanarayan Iyer |date=September 6, 2017 |access-date=February 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/transportation/railways/htt-to-build-indias-first-hyperloop-connecting-amaravati-vijayawada/articleshow/60395268.cms |title=Amaravati to Vijayawada in 5 minutes! This is what hyperloop can do for you |work=The Economic Times |author=ET Bureau |date=September 6, 2017 |access-date=February 7, 2018}}</ref> For yet undisclosed reason, neither the test track that HTT announced in May 2015 nor any other test track has been built in the last 3 years.
===TransPod=== {{Main|TransPod}}
[[TransPod]] Inc. is a Canadian company designing and manufacturing ultra-high-speed tube transportation technology and vehicles.<ref name="transpodabout">{{cite web|title=About TransPod|url=https://transpodhyperloop.com/about-transpod/|website=TransPod|publisher=TransPod Inc|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> In November 2016 TransPod raised a $15 million USD seed round from Angelo Investments, an Italian high-tech holding group, specializing in advanced technologies for the railway, space, and aviation industries.<ref name="techvibes15">{{cite news|title=TransPod Raises $15 Million Seed Round to Commercialize Hyperloop Travel|url=https://techvibes.com/2016/11/23/transpod-raises-15-million-seed-hyperloop|accessdate=October 4, 2017|work=TechVibes|date=November 23, 2016}}</ref>
In September 2017, TransPod released a scientific peer-reviewed publication in the journal Procedia Engineering.<ref name="scidirect">{{cite web|title=TransPod Ultra-High-Speed Tube Transportation: Dynamics of Vehicles and Infrastructure|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S187770581733583X|website=Science Direct|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> The paper was premiered at the [[European Association for Structural Dynamics|EASD]] EURODYN 2017 conference,<ref name="eurodynlectures">{{cite web|title=Keynote Lectures – Eurodyn|url=https://www.eurodyn2017.it/keynote-lectures/|website=Eurodyn 2017|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> and presents the physics of the TransPod system.<ref name="procedia">{{cite journal|last1=Janzen|first1=Ryan|title=TransPod Ultra-High-Speed Tube Transportation: Dynamics of Vehicles and Infrastructure|journal=Procedia Engineering|date=2017|volume=199 |pages=8–17|url=http://transpodresearch.org/files/docs/TransPod_ProcediaEngineering2017_Janzen.pdf|accessdate=October 4, 2017|ref=procedia}}</ref>
TransPod vehicles are being designed to travel at over 1,000 km/h between cities using fully electric propulsion and zero need for fossil fuels.<ref name="procedia" /> The TransPod tube system is distinct from the hyperloop concept proposed by Elon Musk's Hyperloop Alpha white paper. The TransPod system uses moving electromagnetic fields to propel the vehicles with stable levitation off the bottom surface, rather than compressed air.<ref name="procedia" /> TransPod is stated to contain further developments beyond hyperloop.<ref name="tedxtoronto">{{cite web|last1=Janzen|first1=Ryan|title=The future of transportation|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ta9HuJbV-hQ|website=YouTube|publisher=TEDx Toronto|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="betakit20">{{cite news|last1=Galang|first1=Jessica|title=TransPod raises $20 million seed round to continue hyperloop development|url=https://betakit.com/transpod-raises-20-million-seed-round-to-continue-hyperloop-development/|accessdate=October 4, 2017|publisher=BetaKit}}</ref> To achieve fossil-fuel-free propulsion, TransPod "pods" take advantage of electrically-driven [[linear induction motor]] technology, with active real-time control<ref name="procedia" /> and sense-space systems.<ref name="sensespace">{{cite journal|last1=Janzen|first1=R|last2=Mann|first2=S|title=The Physical-Fourier-Amplitude Domain, and Application to Sensing Sensors|journal=Proc. IEEE International Symposium on Multimedia|date=2016|ref=http://eyetap.org/docs/PhysicalFourierAmplitude_JanzenMann2016.pdf}}</ref> The cargo transport TransPod pods will be able to carry payloads of 10–15 tons and have compatibility with wooden pallets, as well as various [[unit load device]]s such as LD3 containers, and AAA containers.<ref name="parisairforum">{{cite web|title=PARIS AIR FORUM – Intervention de Sebastien Gendron – TransPod Hyperloop |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zfw5h9e1b0Q|via=YouTube|publisher=TVLaTribune|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref>
At the [[InnoTrans]] Rail Show 2016 in Berlin, TransPod premiered their vehicle concept, alongside implementation of Coelux technology—an artificial [[skylight]] to emulate natural sunlight within the passenger pods.<ref name="wired">{{cite web|title=This Canadian Hyperloop Concept Features a Faux Sunroof|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/hyperloop-transpod-concept-canada/|website=WIRED|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="itberlin">{{cite web|last1=Wood|first1=Eric|title=Toronto startup's hyperloop technology makes a splash at Berlin trade show|url=http://www.itbusiness.ca/news/toronto-startups-hyperloop-technology-making-a-splash-at-berlin-trade-show/79876|website=itbusiness.ca|publisher=itbusiness.ca}}</ref>
TransPod has partnered with investor Angelo Investments' member companies [[MERMEC]], SITAEL, and Blackshape Aircraft. With international staff of over 1,000 employees, 650 of whom are engineers, they will collaborate with the development and testing of the TransPod tube system<ref name="mermecjoins">{{cite web|title=MERMEC joins Transpod Inc. in hyperloop system development|url=http://www.mermecgroup.com/en/01/press-room/news/1099/mermec-joins-transpod-inc-in-hyperloop-system-development.php|website=MERMEC|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="sitaeljoins">{{cite web|title=Sitael joins TransPod Inc. in hyperloop system development|url=http://www.sitael.com/sitael-joins-transpod-in-hyperloop-system-development/ |website=SITAEL|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="techvibes15" /> It has since expanded from its Toronto, Canada headquarters at [[MaRS Discovery District]]<ref>{{cite web|title=TransPod Inc. - MaRS|url=https://www.marsdd.com/ventures-and-tenants/transpod-inc/|website=MaRS|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="masstransitthree">{{cite web|title=TransPod Accelerates Global Growth with Opening of Three Offices in North America and Europe|url=http://www.masstransitmag.com/press_release/12315853/transpod-accelerates-global-growth-with-opening-of-three-offices-in-north-america-and-europe|website=Mass Transit|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> to open offices in Toulouse, France and Bari, Italy.<ref name="blackshapeglobal">{{cite news|title=TransPod Accelerates Growth Opening Three Global Offices|url=http://www.blackshapeaircraft.com/en/news/transpod-accelerates-growth-opening-three-global-offices/|accessdate=October 4, 2017|publisher=Blackshape Aircraft|date=March 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="inversethree">{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Mike|title=TransPod Wants to Develop a Hyperloop for Canada by 2020|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/29088-transpod-hyperloop-system-canada-italy-france-offices|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=Inverse|date=March 15, 2017}}</ref> TransPod is additionally partnered with university researchers, engineering firm IKOS,<ref name="ikos">{{cite web|title=TransPod partners with IKOS on design of hyperloop pod|url=http://www.canadiangreentech.ca/index.php/news/4803-transpod-partners-with-ikos-on-design-of-hyperloop-pod|website=Canadian Green Tech}}</ref> REC Architecture and [[Liebherr Group|Liebherr-Aerospace]].<ref name="liebherr">{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Rob|title=TransPod Partners with Liebherr-Aerospace to Develop Technology for Hyperloop|url=https://techvibes.com/2017/06/20/transpod-liebherr-aerospace-to-develop-technology-hyperloop|website=Techvibes|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://xlabs.moveworkshop.com/hyperloop-makers-interview-transpod |title=Hyperloop Makers interview: Transpod, an infrastructure startup |author=Sebastian Sjöberg |newspaper=10X Labs |date=March 23, 2016 |access-date=May 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/15/elon-musk-hyperloop-_n_9469762.html |title=Canadian Tech Company Designing A Pod That Travels 600 KM Per Hour |author=Evan Pang |newspaper=The Huffington Post Canada |date=March 15, 2016 |access-date=May 4, 2016}}</ref>
TransPod is developing routes worldwide and in Canada such as Toronto-Montreal,<ref name="torontoStar_transpod">{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/03/13/hyperloop-the-tube-that-promises-to-get-you-from-montreal-to-toronto-in-less-than-30-minutes.html |title=Hyperloop: The tube that promises to get you from Montreal to Toronto in less than 30 minutes |website=Toronto Star |date=March 13, 2016 |access-date=August 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Rapid Transit" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Toronto-Montreal Hyperloop plan could see travel time cut to 39 minutes View description Share|url=https://omny.fm/shows/am640-the-morning-show/toronto-montreal-hyperloop-plan-could-see-travel-t|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=The Morning Show|date=September 18, 2017}}</ref> Toronto-Windsor,<ref name="Daily Hive" /> and Calgary-Edmonton.<ref name="cbccalgarycorridor" /> TransPod is preparing to build a test track for the pod vehicles in Canada.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Brodie|title=Hyperloop startup TransPod scouting Alberta for test track options|url=http://www.metronews.ca/news/calgary/2017/03/31/hyperloop-startup-transpod-scouts-alberta-test-track-options.html|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=Metro News|publisher=Metro News}}</ref> This track will be extendable as part of a full route pending a combination of private and public funding to construct the line.<ref name="cbccalgarycorridor" />
In July 2017, TransPod released an initial cost study<ref name="magnitudeanalysis">{{cite web|title=INITIAL ORDER OF MAGNITUDE ANALYSIS FOR TRANSPOD HYPERLOOP SYSTEM INFRASTRUCTURE |url=https://transpodhyperloop.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/TransPod-infrastructure_EN_July-17-update2.pdf|website=TransPod|publisher=TransPod|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> which outlines the viability of building a hyperloop line in Southwestern Ontario between the cities of Windsor and Toronto.<ref name="hypetechvibes">{{cite news|last1=Kowlton|first1=Thomas |title=Hype for Hyperloop in Canada: Half the Cost, Quadruple the Speed of Proposed High-Speed Rail Plan|url=https://techvibes.com/2017/07/13/hype-for-hyperloop-in-canada-half-the-cost-quadruple-the-speed-of-proposed-high-speed-rail-plan|accessdate=October 4, 2017|publisher=Techvibes|date=July 13, 2017}}</ref> The study indicates a TransPod tube system would cost half the projected cost of a high-speed rail line along the same route, while operating at more than four times the top speed of high speed rail.<ref name="magnitudeanalysis" />
TransPod has announced plans for a test track to be constructed in the town of [[Droux]] near [[Limoges]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Une piste pour l'Hyperloop à l'étude au nord de la Haute-Vienne|url=https://www.lepopulaire.fr/droux/transport/2018/01/25/une-piste-pour-l-hyperloop-a-l-etude-au-nord-de-la-haute-vienne_12713616.html|accessdate=February 28, 2018|publisher=Le Populaire|date=January 25, 2017|ref=lepopdroux}}</ref> in collaboration with the French department of [[Haute-Vienne]]. The proposed test track would exceed 3 km in length, and operate as a half-scale system 2 m in diameter.<ref name="lelpopulaire">{{cite news|last1=Chapperon|first1=Olivier|title=Première esquisse pour la piste d'essai de l'hyperloop en Haute-Vienne|url=https://www.lepopulaire.fr/chateauponsac/economie/innovation/2018/02/20/premiere-esquisse-pour-la-piste-dessai-de-lhyperloop-en-haute-vienne_12746484.html |accessdate=February 28, 2018|publisher=Le Populaire|date=February 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Limoges-Paris en 40 minutes|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4MJeiin7e4 |agency=20 Heures|date=January 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gradt|first1=Jean Michel|title=Train supersonique: HyperloopTT prend de l'avance En savoir plus sur|url=https://www.lesechos.fr/tech-medias/hightech/0301351679820-train-supersonique-hyperloop-prend-de-lavance-2156911.php#xtor=CS1-26|accessdate=February 28, 2018|publisher=Les Echos|date=February 27, 2018}}</ref> In February 2018 Vincent Leonie, vice president of [[Communauté d'agglomération Limoges Métropole|Limoges Métropole]] and a deputy mayor of Limoges,<ref name="limogesmetropole">{{cite web|title=Les élus|url=http://www.agglo-limoges.fr/fr/content/les-elus|website=Limoges Metropole|accessdate=February 28, 2018}}</ref> has announced agreements for the "Hyperloop Limoges" organization have been signed to promote and accelerate the technology.<ref name="lelpopulaire" />
===DGWHyperloop=== Established in 2015, DGWHyperloop is a subsidiary of Dinclix GroundWorks, an engineering company based in [[Indore]], [[India]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dinclixgroundworks.com/hyperloop/Overview-Research.pdf|title=DGWHyperloop - Overview|publisher=Dinclix GroundWorks R&D|accessdate=October 10, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104142739/http://dinclixgroundworks.com/hyperloop/Overview-Research.pdf|archivedate=November 4, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> DGWHyperloop's initial proposals include a Hyperloop-based corridor between [[Delhi]] and [[Mumbai]] called the Delhi Mumbai Hyperloop Corridor (DMHC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dgwhyperloop.com/dmhc.html|title=Delhi-Mumbai Hyperloop Corridor|publisher=DGWHyperloop|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/National/2017-01-18/Proposed-Hyperloop-Project-between-Delhi-and-Mumbai-makes-it-to-Semi-finals-of-Hyperloop-One-Global-Challenge/274219|title=Proposed Hyperloop Project between Delhi and Mumbai|publisher=The Hans India|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref> The company has partnered with many government agencies, private companies, and institutions for its research on Hyperloop.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dgwhyperloop.com/support.html|title=Support Us - DGWHyperloop|publisher=DGWHyperloop|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref> DGWHyperloop is the only [[India]]n company working on implementing the Hyperloop system across the nation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/Hyperloop-Technology-Global-Market-Outlook-2017-2023-1002371575|title=Hyperloop Technology Global Market Outlook 2017-2023|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/hyperloop-technology-market-reach-1-092200748.html|title=Hyperloop Technology Market to Reach $1.3 Billion by 2022 - Key Players are Hyperloop Transportation Technologies, Hyperloop One, DGWHyperloop, TransPod & AECOM|publisher=Yahoo! Finance|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/brandfeatures/venture-capital/article?id=15937|title=Global Hyperloop Technology Market Analysis, Size, Segmentation and Forecast 2017-2023 by Key Players |publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref>
===Arrivo=== [[Arrivo]] is a technology architecture and engineering company founded in Los Angeles in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Crunchbase - Arrivo |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/arrivo#/entity |work=Crunchbase |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> With an early focus on "making hyperloops cheap to use and profitable to operate",<ref>{{cite news |title=Brogan BamBrogan lost control of his first hyperloop start-up. Arrivo is his second chance |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-brogan-bambrogan-arrivo-20170208-story.html |first=Paresh |last=Dave |newspaper=LA Times |date=February 9, 2017 |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> Arrivo aims to shift the transportation industry into a mode of arrival.<ref>{{cite web |title=About Arrivo |url=http://www.arrivo-loop.com/about/ |publisher=Arrivo |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> In November 2017, it disclosed a plan to build a {{cvt|200|mph|km/h|round=5}} link for automobiles to [[Denver International Airport]] using [[maglev]] train technology by 2021.<ref name="fm171114"/>
===Hardt Global Mobility=== Hardt Global Mobility<ref>{{cite web |title=About Hardt |url=https://www.hardtglobalmobility.com/about/ |access-date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> was founded in 2016 in [[Delft]], emerging from the [[TU Delft]] Hyperloop team who won at the SpaceX Pod Competition.<ref name=Delft-NLTimes-2017-01-30>{{cite news |url=http://nltimes.nl/2017/01/30/delft-students-win-elon-musks-hyperloop-competition |title=Delft students win Elon Musk's hyperloop competition |first=Janene |last=Pieters |work=NL Times |location=The Netherlands |date=January 30, 2017 |access-date=April 17, 2018}}</ref>
The Dutch team is setting up a full-scale testing center for hyperloop technology in Delft. Hardt has received over €600,000 in funding for the initial rounds of testing, with plans to raise more to build a high-speed test line by 2019.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sterling |first1=Toby|title=Dutch group sets up hyperloop test center|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-netherlands-hyperloop/dutch-group-sets-up-hyperloop-test-center-idUSKBN18S418|accessdate=October 11, 2017|publisher=Reuters|date=June 1, 2017}}</ref> At the unveiling of the test track, Dutch Minister of Infrastructure and Environment [[Melanie Schultz van Haegen|Schultz van Haegen]] said a Hyperloop system could help cement the Netherlands' position as a gateway to Europe by transporting freight arriving at Rotterdam's sprawling port.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Corder|first1=Mike|title=Dutch Testing Tube Unveiled for Hyperloop Transport System |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-01/dutch-testing-tube-unveiled-for-hyperloop-transport-system|accessdate=October 11, 2017|publisher=Bloomberg|date=June 1, 2017}}</ref>
In October 9, 2017 a report was released with information from Hardt Global Mobility and Hyperloop One. The report has been sent to the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Dutch House of Representatives]] and judges the added value of a hyperloop test track facility. The report recommends building a test track of 5 km in [[Flevoland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rapport 'Hyperloop in The Netherlands'|url=https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/rapporten/2017/10/09/rapport-hyperloop-in-the-netherlands|website=Rijksoverheid|accessdate=October 11, 2017}}</ref>
===Hyper Chariot=== Hyper Chariot is a startup company based in [[Santa Monica]], United States, that began promoting itself in June 2017. The company has an ambitious plan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2017/07/10/blazing-hyper-chariot-pods-can-travel-4000-miles-per-hour.html |title=BLAZING: 'Hyper Chariot' pods can travel 4,000 miles per hour |first=Walt |last=Bonner |publisher=Fox News |location=US |date=July 10, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref> On July 27, 2017 it announced a partnership with AML Superconductivity and Magnetics for the development of the vehicle and related propulsion system.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/HyperChariot/posts/918729294934286 |title=Hyper Chariot |via=Facebook |access-date=October 6, 2017}}</ref>
===Zeleros=== Zeleros<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/18270068/ |title=Zeleros: Overview |website=LinkedIn |access-date=November 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeleros.com/|title=Zeleros {{!}} Because time matters|website=Zeleros |access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> was founded in [[Valencia]] (Spain) in November 2016 by Daniel Orient (CTO), David Pistoni (CEO) and Juan Vicén (CMO), former leaders of the [[Hyperloop UPV]] team from [[Polytechnic University of Valencia|Universitat Politècnica de València]]. The team was awarded "Top Design Concept" and "Propulsion/Compression Subsystem Technical Excellence" by [[SpaceX]] at Hyperloop Design Weekend.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2016/mit-leads-in-first-round-of-spacexs-hyperloop-contest-but-uw-is-in-the-race/|title=MIT leads in first round of Elon Musk's Hyperloop contest, but UW is in the race|date=2016-02-01|work=GeekWire|access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> After building Spain's first Hyperloop prototype with the support of Purdue University,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.purdue.edu/newsroom/releases/2017/Q3/purdue-takes-collaborative-hyperloop-pod-to-spacex-competition.html|title=Purdue takes collaborative Hyperloop pod to SpaceX competition - Purdue University|last=Service|first=Purdue News|website=www.purdue.edu |access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> and building a 12-meter research test-track in Spain<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marcaespana.es/en/news/society/first-hyperloop-test-track-valencia|title=Marca España {{!}} First Hyperloop test track in Valencia|website=marcaespana.es |access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> at the University, the company was awarded in November 2017 the international Everis Foundation prize<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.everis.com/usa/en/news/newsroom/everis-foundation-awards-hyperloop|title=The everis foundation awards a Spanish startup's 'Hyperloop' technology project with €60,000|date=November 22, 2017 |work=everis USA|access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> and wants to develop new technologies for a more efficient and sustainable transportation.
==Hyperloop pod competition== {{Main|Hyperloop pod competition}} [[File:Hyperloop pod competition tube.jpg|thumb|Hyperloop pod competition]]
A number of student and non-student teams were participating in a [[Hyperloop pod competition]] in 2015–16, and at least 22 of them built hardware to compete on a sponsored hyperloop test track in mid-2016.<ref name=verge20160130>{{cite news |last=Hawkins |first=Andrew J. |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/30/10877442/elon-musk-spacex-hyperloop-competition-awards |title=MIT wins SpaceX's Hyperloop competition, and Elon Musk made a cameo |work=The Verge |date=January 30, 2016 |access-date=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
In June 2015, [[SpaceX]] announced that they would sponsor a Hyperloop pod design competition, and would build a {{convert|1|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} subscale test track near SpaceX's headquarters in [[Hawthorne, California]] for the competitive event in 2016.<ref name="NBChyperloop"/><ref name="hyper-pod-competition"/> SpaceX stated in their announcement, "Neither SpaceX nor Elon Musk is affiliated with any Hyperloop companies. While we are not developing a commercial Hyperloop ourselves, we are interested in helping to accelerate development of a functional Hyperloop prototype."<ref name="spacexhyperloop"/>
More than 700 teams had submitted preliminary applications by July,<ref name="binsider20150623"/> and detailed competition rules were released in August.<ref name=rules_v20/> ''Intent to Compete'' submissions were due in September 2015 with more detailed tube and technical specification released by SpaceX in October. A preliminary design briefing was held in November 2015, where more than 120 student engineering teams were selected to submit ''Final Design Packages'' due by January 13, 2016.<ref name=gw20151215>{{cite news |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2015/124-teams-sign-up-for-spacex-founder-elon-musks-hyperloop-pod-race |title=More than 120 teams picked for SpaceX founder Elon Musk's Hyperloop contest |work=Geekwire.com |first=Alan |last=Boyle |date=December 15, 2015 |access-date=December 16, 2015}}</ref>
A ''Design Weekend'' was held at [[Texas A&M University]] January 29–30, 2016, for all invited entrants.<ref name="tamu201510"/> Engineers from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] were named the winners of the competition. Finishing second was [[Delft University of Technology]] from the Netherlands, followed by the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], [[Virginia Tech]], and the [[University of California, Irvine]].<ref name="verge20160130"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/jan/31/mit-students-win-competition-to-design-elon-musks-hyperloop-travel-system |title=Hyperloop: MIT students win contest to design Elon Musk's 700mph travel pods |work=[[The Guardian]] |agency=Associated Press |date=January 30, 2016 |access-date=February 19, 2016}}</ref> While the MIT team took best overall, the [[University of Washington]] team won the Safety Subsystem Award and Delft University won the Pod Innovation Award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.technobuffalo.com/2016/02/01/hyperloop-competition-winners-announced-see-the-top-design |title=Hyperloop competition winners announced, see the top design |work=TechnoBuffalo |first=Jacob |last=Kleinman |date=February 1, 2016 |access-date=February 19, 2016}}</ref> In the Design Category, the winner team was [[Hyperloop UPV]] from Universitat Politecnica de Valencia, Spain.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hyperloop.tamu.edu/awards/|title=Awards|publisher=Texas A & M University College of Engineering |year=2017 |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> On January 29, 2017, Delft Hyperloop (Delft University of Technology) won the final stage of the SpaceX Hyperloop competition,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tudelft.nl/en/2017/tu-delft/tu-delft-students-win-hyperloop-pod-competition/ |title=TU Delft students win Hyperloop Pod Competition |publisher=Delft University of Technology |location=The Netherlands |date=January 30, 2017 |access-date=June 3, 2017}}</ref> ahead of the [[Technical University of Munich]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.mit.edu/2017/safe-at-any-speed-mit-hyperloop-0214 |title=Safe at any speed |first=Meg |last=Murphy |work=MIT News |location=Cambridge, MA, USA |date=February 14, 2017 |access-date=August 29, 2017}}</ref>
==Criticism and human factor considerations== Some critics of Hyperloop focus on the experience—possibly unpleasant and frightening—of riding in a narrow, sealed, windowless capsule inside a sealed steel tunnel, that is subjected to significant [[g-force|acceleration forces]]; high noise levels due to air being compressed and ducted around the capsule at near-sonic speeds; and the vibration and jostling.<ref name="insider20130820"/> Even if the tube is initially smooth, ground may shift with seismic activity. At high speeds, even minor deviations from a straight path may add considerable buffeting.<ref name="verge20130816"/> This is in addition to practical and logistical questions regarding how to best deal with safety issues such as equipment malfunction, accidents, and emergency evacuations.
Other [[maglev]] trains are already in use, which avoid much of the added costs of Hyperloop. The [[SCMaglev]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/21/japans-maglev-train-notches-up-new-world-speed-record-in-test-run|title=Japan's maglev train breaks world speed record with 600km/h test run|first=Justin|last=McCurry|date=April 21, 2015|website=the Guardian}}</ref> in Japan has demonstrated {{convert|603|km/h|mph|abbr=on|0}} without a vacuum tube, by using an extremely aerodynamic train design. It also avoids the cost and time required to pressurize and depressurize the exit and entry points of a Hyperloop tube.
There is also the criticism of design technicalities in the tube system. Prof. John Hansman has stated problems, such as how a slight misalignment in the tube would be compensated for and the potential interplay between the air cushion and the low-pressure air. He has also questioned what would happen if the power were to go out when the pod was miles away from a city. Prof. Richard Muller has also expressed concern regarding "[the Hyperloop's] novelty and the vulnerability of its tubes, [which] would be a tempting target for terrorists", and that the system could be disrupted by everyday dirt and grime.<ref name="Mercury-2016-09-16"/>
==Political and economic considerations== The alpha proposal projected that cost savings compared with conventional rail would come from a combination of several factors. The small profile and elevated nature of the alpha route would enable Hyperloop to be constructed primarily in the median of [[Interstate 5 in California|Interstate 5]]. However, whether this would be truly feasible is a matter of debate. The low profile would reduce tunnel boring requirements and the light weight of the capsules is projected to reduce construction costs over conventional passenger rail. It was asserted that there would be less [[right-of-way]] opposition and environmental impact as well due to its small, sealed, elevated profile versus that of a rail easement;<ref name="AlphaSpaceX"/> however, other commentators contend that a smaller footprint does not guarantee less opposition.<ref name="GGW"/> In criticizing this assumption, [[mass transportation]] writer Alon Levy said, "In reality, an all-elevated system (which is what Musk proposes with the Hyperloop) is a bug rather than a feature. Central Valley land is cheap; pylons are expensive, as can be readily seen by the costs of elevated highways and trains all over the world".<ref name="NationalReview"/><ref name="WaPoWonkBlog"/> Michael Anderson, a professor of agricultural and resource economics at [[UC Berkeley]], predicted that costs would amount to around {{US$|100 billion}}.<ref name="AJE"/>
The Hyperloop white paper suggests that {{US$|20}} of each one-way passenger ticket between Los Angeles and San Francisco would be sufficient to cover initial [[capital (economics)|capital costs]], based on amortizing the cost of Hyperloop over 20 years with ridership projections of 7.4 million per year in each direction and does not include operating costs (although the proposal asserts that electric costs would be covered by solar panels). No total [[fare|ticket price]] was suggested in the alpha design.<ref name="AlphaSpaceX"/> The projected ticket price has been questioned by Dan Sperling, director of the [[Institute of Transportation Studies]] at [[UC Davis]], who stated that "there's no way the economics on that would ever work out."<ref name="AJE"/>
The early cost estimates of the Hyperloop are a subject of debate. A number of economists and transportation experts have expressed the belief that the {{US$|6 billion}} price tag dramatically understates the cost of designing, developing, constructing, and testing an all-new form of transportation.<ref name="NYT-Bilton"/><ref name="AJE"/><ref name="GGW"/><ref name="WaPoWonkBlog"/> ''The Economist'' said that the estimates are unlikely to "be immune to the [[cost overrun|hypertrophication of cost]] that every other grand infrastructure project seems doomed to suffer."<ref name="economist20130817"/>
Political impediments to the construction of such a project in California will be very large. There is a great deal of "political and [[reputation capital]]" invested in the existing mega-project of [[California High-Speed Rail]].<ref name="economist20130817"/> Replacing that with a different design would not be straightforward given California's political economy. Texas has been suggested as an alternate for its more amenable political and economic environment.<ref name="economist20130817"/>
Building a successful Hyperloop sub-scale demonstration project could reduce the political impediments and improve cost estimates. Musk has suggested that he may be personally involved in building a demonstration prototype of the Hyperloop concept, including funding the development effort.<ref name="gm20130813"/><ref name="economist20130817"/>
The solar panels Musk plans to install along the length of the Hyperloop system have been criticized by Prof. Roger Goodall, as not being feasible enough to return enough energy to power the Hyperloop system, arguing that the air pumps and propulsion would require much more power than the solar panels could generate.<ref name="Mercury-2016-09-16"/>
==Related projects==
===Historical===
The concept of transportation of passengers in pneumatic tubes is not new. The first patent to transport goods in tubes was taken out in 1799 by the British mechanical engineer and inventor [[George Medhurst]]. In 1812, Medhurst wrote a book detailing his idea of transporting passengers and goods through air-tight tubes using air propulsion.<ref name="business20130715"/>
In the early 1800s, there were other similar systems proposed or experimented with and were generally known as an [[atmospheric railway]] although this term is also used for systems where the propulsion is provided by a separate pneumatic tube to the train tunnel itself.
One of the earliest was the [[Dalkey Atmospheric Railway]] which operated near Dublin between 1844 and 1854.
The [[Crystal Palace pneumatic railway]] operated in London around 1864 and used large fans, some {{convert|22|ft|m|abbr=on|1}} in diameter, that were powered by a steam engine. The tunnels are now lost but the line operated successfully for over a year.
Operated from 1870 to 1873, the [[Beach Pneumatic Transit]] was a one-block-long prototype of an underground tube transport public transit system in [[New York City]]. The system worked at near-atmospheric pressure, and the passenger car moved by means of higher-pressure air applied to the back of the car while somewhat lower pressure was maintained on the front of the car.<ref name="sa18700305"/>
In the 1910s, vacuum trains were first described by American rocket pioneer [[Robert Goddard]].<ref name=economist20130817/> While the Hyperloop has significant innovations over early proposals for reduced pressure or vacuum-tube transportation apparatus, the work of Goddard "appears to have the greatest overlap with the Hyperloop".<ref name="gm20130822"/>
Princeton Physicist [[Gerard K. O'Neill]] wrote about transcontinental trains using magnetic propulsion in his book "2081: A Hopeful View of the Human Future". While a work of fiction, this book was an attempt to predict future technologies in everyday life. In his prediction, he envisioned these trains which used magnetic levitation running in underground tunnels which had much of the air evacuated to increase speed and reduce friction. He also demonstrated a scale prototype device that accelerated a mass using magnetic propulsion to high speeds. It was called a mass driver and was a central theme in his non-fiction book on space colonization "The High Frontier".
[[Swissmetro]] was a proposal to run a maglev train in a low-pressure environment. Concessions were granted to Swissmetro in the early 2000s to connect the Swiss cities of St. Gallen, Zurich, Basel, and Geneva. Studies of commercial feasibility reached differing conclusions and the vactrain was never built.<ref name="swissmetro"/>
China was reported to be building a vacuum based {{convert|1000|km/h|mph|abbr=on|order=flip|round=50}} maglev train in August 2010 according to a laboratory at Jiaotong University. It was expected to cost {{CNY|10–20 million|link=yes}} ({{US$|2.95 million}} at the August 2010 exchange rate) more per kilometer than regular high-speed rail.<ref name="engadgetsumohurd20100804"/> {{As of|2017|5}}, it has not been built.
===Current=== The [[ET3 Global Alliance]] (ET3) was founded by Daryl Oster in 1997 with the goal of establishing a global transportation system using passenger capsules in frictionless [[magnetic levitation|maglev]] full-vacuum tubes. Oster and his team met with Elon Musk on September 18, 2013, to discuss the technology,<ref name="futurist20131030"/> resulting in Musk promising an investment in a {{convert|3|mi|km|0|adj=on}} prototype of ET3's proposed design.<ref name="denver20130809"/>{{update after|2015|6|17}}<!-- so what is the status of this? are ET3 building anything? -->
==In popular culture== There are multiple examples of depressurized tubes in literature and media going back to the 19th century. [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]]'s 1972 book ''[[Tunnel Through the Deeps]]'' is an early [[steampunk]] book that give explicit details about how such a system would work both on land and at sea – including the use of underwater bridges to float the tubes across the depths beyond the continental shelf. [[Gene Roddenberry]]'s follow-on to ''[[Star Trek]]'', ''[[Genesis II (film)|Genesis II]]'', used a very similar concept – called a "subshuttle" in the program – to quickly move characters from place to place.
