revision.comment: /* Sections of IEC 61131 */
revision.text:
{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=January 2012}} '''IEC 61131''' is an [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] standard for [[programmable logic controller|programmable controllers]]. It was known as IEC 1131 before the change in numbering system by IEC. The parts of the IEC 61131 standard are prepared and maintained working group 7, programmable control systems, of subcommittee SC 65B of [[List of IEC technical committees|Technical Committee]] TC65 of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]].
==Sections of IEC 61131== Standard ''IEC 61131'' is divided into several parts:<ref>[https://webstore.iec.ch/searchform&q=61131 All parts available for "IEC 61131"], IEC Webstore</ref> * Part 1: General information. It is the introductory chapter; it contains definitions of terms that are used in the subsequent parts of the standard and outlines the main functional properties and characteristics of PLCs. * Part 2: Equipment requirements and tests - establishes the requirements and associated tests for programmable controllers and their peripherals. This standard prescribes: the normal service conditions and requirements (for example, requirements related with climatic conditions, transport and storage, electrical service, etc.); functional requirements (power supply & memory, digital and analog [[I/O]]s); functional type tests and verification (requirements and tests on environmental, vibration, drop, free fall, I/O, power ports, etc.) and [[electromagnetic compatibility]] (EMC) requirements and tests that programmable controllers must implement. This standard can serve as a basis in the evaluation of safety programmable controllers to [[IEC 61508]]. * [[IEC 61131-3|Part 3]]: Programming languages * [[IEC 61131-4|Part 4]]: User guidelines * [[IEC 61131-5|Part 5]]: Communications * [[IEC 61131-6|Part 6]]: Functional safety * [[IEC 61131-7|Part 7]]: [[Fuzzy control]] programming * [[IEC 61131-8|Part 8]]: Guidelines for the application and implementation of programming languages * [[IEC 61131-9|Part 9]]: Single-drop digital communication interface for small sensors and actuators (SDCI, marketed as [[IO-Link]]<ref>http://io-link.com/en/Technology/what_is_IO-Link.php?thisID=76</ref><ref>https://webstore.iec.ch/publication/4558</ref><ref>http://www.io-link.com/share/Downloads/Spec-Interface/IOL-Interface-Spec_10002_V112_Jul13.pdf</ref>)
A further part is currently being worked on: * Part 10: XML exchange formats for programs according to IEC 61131-3
==Related Standards== [[IEC 61499]] Function Block
[[PLCopen]] has developed several standards and working groups. * TC1 - Standards * TC2 - Functions * TC3 - Certification * TC4 - Communications * TC5 - Safe Software * TC6 - [[XML]] * Motion Control Library * Presentation on IEC 61131-3
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * R.W. Lewis, ''Modelling control systems using IEC 61499'' * R.W. Lewis, ''Programming industrial control systems using IEC 1131-3'' * K.H. John & M. Tiegelkamp, ''IEC 61131-3: Programming Industrial Automation Systems'' == External links == * {{IEC|61131}} * PLCopen.org - International Not-For-Profit organization that supports and extends the IEC 61131 programming standard. http://www.PLCopen.org * PLCopen North America http://www.PLCopen-NA.org Part of PLCopen * XML Standard Documentation: http://www.plcopen.org/pages/tc6_xml/ {{List of IEC standards}} [[Category:Electronic engineering]] [[Category:IEC standards|#61131]] [[Category:Programmable logic controllers]]

revision.comment: /* Experimental mechanism */
revision.text:
{{Infobox observatory |name=IceCube Neutrino Observatory |background= |image=[[File:Icecube-architecture-diagram2009.PNG|300px]] |caption=Diagram of the IceCube strings |organization=IceCube collaboration |code= |location=[[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]] |coords={{coord|89|59|24|S|63|27|11|W|region:AQ|display=inline,title}} |altitude= |weather= |established=<!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |closed= |website={{URL|http://icecube.wisc.edu/}} |telescope1_name=Telescope |telescope1_type=[[Neutrino detector|Neutrino]] |telescope2_name= |telescope2_type= |telescope3_name= |telescope3_type= |telescope4_name= |telescope4_type= }} The '''IceCube Neutrino Observatory''' (or simply '''IceCube''') is a [[neutrino observatory]] constructed at the [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]] in [[Antarctica]].<ref> {{Cite journal |date = 30 June 2009 |title = IceCube: Extreme Science! |journal = Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research A |volume = 601 |issue = 3 |pages = 294 |url = http://www.icecube.wisc.edu/info/ |accessdate = 2009-10-15 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100314073730/http://www.icecube.wisc.edu/info/ |archivedate = 14 March 2010 |df = |last1 = Abbasi |first1 = R |last2 = Ackermann |first2 = M |last3 = Adams |first3 = J |last4 = Ahlers |first4 = M |last5 = Ahrens |first5 = J |last6 = Andeen |first6 = K |last7 = Auffenberg |first7 = J |last8 = Bai |first8 = X |last9 = Baker |first9 = M |last10 = Barwick |first10 = S. W |last11 = Bay |first11 = R |last12 = Bazo Alba |first12 = J. L |last13 = Beattie |first13 = K |last14 = Becka |first14 = T |last15 = Becker |first15 = J. K |last16 = Becker |first16 = K. -H |last17 = Berghaus |first17 = P |last18 = Berley |first18 = D |last19 = Bernardini |first19 = E |last20 = Bertrand |first20 = D |last21 = Besson |first21 = D. Z |last22 = Bingham |first22 = B |last23 = Blaufuss |first23 = E |last24 = Boersma |first24 = D. J |last25 = Bohm |first25 = C |last26 = Bolmont |first26 = J |last27 = Böser |first27 = S |last28 = Botner |first28 = O |last29 = Braun |first29 = J |last30 = Breeder |first30 = D |displayauthors = 29 }}</ref> Its thousands of sensors are located under the Antarctic ice, distributed over a [[cubic kilometre]].
Similar to its predecessor, the [[Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array]] (AMANDA)<!-- which relied on analog data transmission except for one digital development string -->, IceCube consists of spherical optical sensors called Digital Optical Modules (DOMs), each with a [[photomultiplier tube]] (PMT)<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |display-authors=etal |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |year=2010 |title=Calibration and Characterization of the IceCube Photomultiplier Tube |journal=[[Nuclear Instruments and Methods A]] |volume=618 |issue= 1–3|pages=139–152 |arxiv=1002.2442 |bibcode=2010NIMPA.618..139A |doi=10.1016/j.nima.2010.03.102 }}</ref> and a single-board data acquisition computer which sends digital data to the counting house on the surface above the array.<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |display-authors=etal |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |year=2009 |title=The IceCube Data Acquisition System: Signal Capture, Digitization, and Timestamping |journal=[[Nuclear Instruments and Methods A]] |volume=601 |issue= 3|pages=294–316 |arxiv=0810.4930 |bibcode=2009NIMPA.601..294T |doi=10.1016/j.nima.2009.01.001 }}</ref> IceCube was completed on 18 December 2010.<ref>[http://icecube.wisc.edu/ IceCube Neutrino Observatory]</ref>
DOMs are deployed on strings of 60 modules each at depths between 1,450 to 2,450 meters into holes melted in the ice using a hot water drill. IceCube is designed to look for point sources of [[neutrino]]s in the [[electronvolt|TeV]] range to explore the highest-energy astrophysical processes.
In November 2013 it was announced that IceCube had detected 28 neutrinos that likely originated outside the [[Solar System]].<ref> {{cite journal |author=IceCube Collaboration |year=2013 |title=Evidence for High-Energy Extraterrestrial Neutrinos at the IceCube Detector |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=342 |issue=6161 |pages=1242856 |arxiv=1311.5238 |bibcode=2013Sci...342E...1I |doi=10.1126/science.1242856 |pmid=24264993 }}</ref>
==Construction== IceCube is part of a series of projects developed and supervised by the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]. Collaboration and funding are provided by numerous other universities and research institutions worldwide.<ref>[http://icecube.wisc.edu/collaboration/institutions IceCube Collaborating Organizations]</ref> Construction of IceCube was only possible during the Antarctic [[austral summer]] from November to February, when permanent sunlight allows for 24-hour drilling. Construction began in 2005, when the first IceCube string was deployed and sufficient data was collected to verify that the optical sensors functioned correctly.<ref name="spcr-1"> {{cite press |author=K. Hutchison |date=24 October 2005 |title=IceCube - One hole done, 79 more to go |url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=18108 |publisher=SpaceRef.com |accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref> In the 2005–2006 season, an additional eight strings were deployed, making IceCube the largest [[neutrino telescope]] in the world. [[File:IceCube drill camp 2009.jpg|thumb|500px|right|IceCube drilling tower and hose reel in December 2009]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Season ! Strings Installed ! Total Strings |- | 2005 | 1 | 1 |- | 2005–2006 | 8 | 9 |- | 2006–2007 | 13 | 22 |- | 2007–2008 | 18 | 40 |- | 2008–2009 | 19 | 59 |- | 2009–2010 | 20 | 79 |- | 2010 | 7 | 86 |}
Construction was completed on 17 December 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://icecube.wisc.edu/complete.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225234422/http://icecube.wisc.edu/complete.php |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.news.wisc.edu/18796 World's largest neutrino observatory completed at South Pole (Dec. 17, 2010)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The total cost of the project was $279 million.<ref>https://icecube.wisc.edu/about/faq#cost</ref> The facility is maintained by two staff members at the [[Amundsen–Scott station]] and costs very little to operate.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Overbye |first1=Dennis |authorlink1=Dennis Overbye |title=It Came From a Black Hole, and Landed in Antarctica |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/12/science/space-neutrinos-blazar.html |accessdate=21 July 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=12 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==Sub-detectors== [[File:ICECUBE dom taklampa.jpg|thumb|right|"Taklampa," one of the Digital Optical Modules of IceCube's hole #85]] The IceCube Neutrino Observatory is composed of several sub-detectors in addition to the main in-ice array.
*AMANDA, the [[Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array]], was the first part built, and it served as a [[proof-of-concept]] for IceCube. AMANDA was turned off in May 2009.<ref> {{cite journal |last1=Aartsen |first1=M. G. |display-authors=etal |year=2013 |title=Measurement of South Pole ice transparency with the IceCube LED calibration system |journal=[[Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research A]] |volume=711 |issue=73|pages=73–89 |doi=10.1016/j.nima.2013.01.054 |arxiv=1301.5361 |bibcode=2013NIMPA.711...73A }}</ref> *The IceTop array is a series of [[Cherenkov detector]]s on the surface of the glacier, with two detectors approximately above each IceCube string. IceTop is used as a [[cosmic ray shower]] detector, for cosmic ray composition studies and [[coincidence method|coincident event]] tests: if a [[muon]] is observed going through IceTop, it cannot be from a neutrino interacting in the ice. *The Deep Core Low-Energy Extension is a densely instrumented region of the IceCube array which extends the observable energies below 100 [[electronvolt|GeV]]. The Deep Core strings are deployed at the center (in the surface plane) of the larger array, deep in the clearest ice at the bottom of the array (between 1760 and 2450 m deep). There are no Deep Core DOMs between 1850 m and 2107 m depth, as the ice is not as clear in those layers.
PINGU (Precision IceCube Next Generation Upgrade) is a proposed extension that will allow detection of low energy neutrinos (GeV energy scale), with uses including determining the neutrino mass hierarchy, precision measurement of atmospheric neutrino oscillation (both tau neutrino appearance and muon neutrino disappearance), and searching for [[Weakly interacting massive particles|WIMP]] annihilation in the Sun.<ref> {{Cite news |url=http://icecube.wisc.edu/news/view/186 |title=IceCube looks to the future with PINGU |date=30 Dec 2013 |work= |access-date= }}</ref> A vision has been presented for a larger observatory, IceCube-Gen2.<ref> {{Cite arxiv |last1=Aartsen |first1=M. G. |display-authors=etal |collaboration=Icecube-Gen2 Collaboration |date=18 Dec 2014 |title=IceCube-Gen2: A Vision for the Future of Neutrino Astronomy in Antarctica |eprint=1412.5106 |class=astro-ph.HE }}</ref>
==Experimental mechanism== Neutrinos are [[electric charge|electrically neutral]] [[lepton]]s, and interact very rarely with matter. When they do react with the molecules of water in the ice, they can create charged leptons ([[electron]]s, [[muon]]s, or [[tau lepton|tau]]s). These charged leptons can, if they are energetic enough, emit [[Cherenkov radiation]]. This happens when the charged particle travels through the ice faster than the [[speed of light]] in the ice, similar to the [[bow shock]] of a boat traveling faster than the waves it crosses. This light can then be detected by [[photomultiplier|photomultiplier tube]]s within the digital optical modules making up IceCube.
The signals from the PMTs are digitized and then sent to the surface of the glacier on a cable. These signals are collected in a surface counting house, and some of them are sent north via satellite for further analysis. Since 2014, hard drives rather than tape store the balance of the data which is sent north once a year via ship. Once the data reaches experimenters, they can reconstruct [[kinematical]] parameters of the incoming neutrino. High-energy neutrinos may cause a large signal in the detector, pointing back to their origin. Clusters of such neutrino directions indicate point sources of neutrinos.
Each of the above steps requires a certain minimum energy, and thus IceCube is sensitive mostly to high energy neutrinos, in the range of 10<sup>11</sup> to about 10<sup>21</sup> [[electronvolt|eV]].<ref name=hlz-nrc> {{cite web |author=F. Halzen |date=June 2002 |url=http://icecube.wisc.edu/pub_and_doc/reviews_and_meetings/June2002_NRC-Review/presentations/nrc_halzen.pdf |title=IceCube: A Kilometer-Scale Neutrino Observatory |accessdate=2009-10-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060909003706/http://icecube.wisc.edu/pub_and_doc/reviews_and_meetings/June2002_NRC-Review/presentations/nrc_halzen.pdf |archivedate=September 9, 2006 |df= }}</ref>
IceCube is more sensitive to [[muon]]s than other charged leptons, because they are the most penetrating and thus have the longest tracks in the detector. Thus, of the neutrino flavors, IceCube is most sensitive to [[muon neutrino]]s. An [[electron]] resulting from an [[electron neutrino]] event typically [[scattering|scatters]] several times before losing enough energy to fall below the [[Cherenkov radiation|Cherenkov]] threshold; this means that [[electron neutrino]] events cannot typically be used to point back to sources, but they are more likely to be fully contained in the detector, and thus they can be useful for energy studies. These events are more spherical, or "cascade"-like, than "[[particle track|track]]"-like; muon neutrino events are more track-like.
[[Tau lepton]]s can also create cascade events; but are short-lived and cannot travel very far before decaying, and are thus usually indistinguishable from electron cascades. A tau could be distinguished from an electron with a "double bang" event, where a cascade is seen both at the tau creation and decay. This is only possible with very high energy taus. Hypothetically, to resolve a tau track, the tau would need to travel at least from one DOM to an adjacent DOM (17 m) before decaying. As the average lifetime of a tau is {{val|2.9|e=-13|u=s}}, a tau traveling at near the speed of light would require 20 TeV of energy for every meter traveled.<ref>Speed of light ({{val|299792458|u=m/s}}) × average lifetime ({{val|2.9|e=-13|u=s}}) = {{val|8.711|e=-5|u=m}}</ref> Realistically, an experimenter would need more space than just one DOM to the next to distinguish two cascades, so double bang searches are centered at [[electronvolt|PeV]] scale energies. Such searches are underway but have not so far isolated a double bang event from background events.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}<!-- cite ICRC? -->
There is a large [[background noise|background]] of muons created not by neutrinos from astrophysical sources but by [[cosmic rays]] impacting the [[atmosphere]] above the detector. There are about 10<sup>6</sup> times more cosmic ray muons than neutrino-induced muons observed in IceCube.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} Most of these can be rejected using the fact that they are traveling downwards. Most of the remaining (up-going) events are from neutrinos, but most of these neutrinos are from cosmic rays hitting the far side of the Earth; some unknown fraction may come from [[astronomical source]]s, and these neutrinos are the key to IceCube point source searches. Estimates predict the detection of about 75 upgoing neutrinos per day in the fully constructed IceCube detector. The arrival directions of these astrophysical neutrinos are the points with which the IceCube telescope maps the sky. To distinguish these two types of neutrinos statistically, the direction and energy of the incoming neutrino is estimated from its collision by-products. Unexpected excesses in energy or excesses from a given spatial direction indicate an extraterrestrial source.
==Experimental goals==
===Point sources of high energy neutrinos=== A point source of neutrinos could help explain the mystery of the origin of the highest energy cosmic rays. These cosmic rays have energies high enough that they cannot be contained by [[galactic magnetic fields]] (their [[gyroradius|gyroradii]] are larger than the radius of the galaxy), so they are believed to come from extra-galactic sources. Astrophysical events which are cataclysmic enough to create such high energy particles would probably also create high energy neutrinos, which could travel to the Earth with very little deflection, because neutrinos interact so rarely. IceCube could observe these neutrinos: its observable energy range is about 100 GeV to several PeV. The more energetic an event is, the larger volume IceCube may detect it in; in this sense, IceCube is more similar to Cherenkov telescopes like the [[Pierre Auger Observatory]] (an array of Cherenkov detecting tanks) than it is to other neutrino experiments, such as [[Super-K]] (with inward-facing PMTs fixing the fiducial volume).
IceCube is more sensitive to point sources in the northern hemisphere than in the southern hemisphere. It can observe astrophysical neutrino signals from any direction, but neutrinos coming from the direction of the southern hemisphere are swamped by the cosmic-ray muon background. Thus, early IceCube point source searches focus on the northern hemisphere, and the extension to southern hemisphere point sources takes extra work.<ref name=south-pntsrc> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |display-authors=etal |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |year=2009 |title=Extending the Search for Neutrino Point Sources with IceCube above the Horizon |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=103 |issue=22 |page=221102 |arxiv=0911.2338 |bibcode=2009PhRvL.103v1102A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.103.221102 |pmid=20366087 |hdl=2440/76771 }}</ref>
Although IceCube is expected to detect very few neutrinos (relative to the number of photons detected by more traditional telescopes), it should have very high resolution with the ones that it does find. Over several years of operation, it could produce a flux map of the northern hemisphere similar to existing maps like that of the [[cosmic microwave background]], or [[gamma ray telescope]]s, which use particle terminology more like IceCube. Likewise, [[KM3NeT]] could complete the map for the southern hemisphere.
IceCube scientists may have detected their first neutrinos on January 29, 2006.<ref> {{cite web |author=K. Mizoguchi |date=17 February 2006 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/discoveries/2006-02-17-icecube-project_x.htm |title=Scientists find first neutrinos in 'IceCube' project |website=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref>
===Gamma ray bursts coincident with neutrinos=== When [[proton]]s collide with one another or with [[photon]]s, the result is usually [[pion]]s. Charged pions decay into [[muon]]s and [[muon neutrino]]s whereas neutral pions decay into [[gamma rays]]. Potentially, the neutrino flux and the gamma ray flux may coincide in certain sources such as [[gamma ray burst]]s and [[supernova remnant]]s, indicating the elusive nature of their origin. Data from IceCube is being used in conjunction with gamma-ray satellites like [[Swift Gamma-Ray Burst Mission|Swift]] or [[Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope|Fermi]] for this goal. IceCube has not observed any neutrinos in coincidence with gamma ray bursts, but is able to use this search to constrain neutrino flux to values less than those predicted by the current models.<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |display-authors=etal |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |year=2011 |title=Limits on Neutrino Emission from Gamma-Ray Bursts with the 40 String IceCube Detector |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=106 |issue=14 |page=141101 |arxiv=1101.1448 |bibcode=2011PhRvL.106n1101A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.106.141101 |pmid=21561178 }}</ref>
===Indirect dark matter searches=== [[Weakly interacting massive particle]] (WIMP) [[dark matter]] could be gravitationally captured by massive objects like the [[Sun]] and accumulate in the [[solar core|core of the Sun]]. With a high enough density of these particles, they would [[annihilation|annihilate]] with each other at a significant rate. The decay products of this annihilation could decay into neutrinos, which could be observed by IceCube as an excess of neutrinos from the direction of the Sun. This technique of looking for the decay products of WIMP annihilation is called indirect, as opposed to direct searches which look for dark matter interacting within a contained, instrumented volume. Solar WIMP searches are more sensitive to [[spin (physics)|spin]]-dependent WIMP models than many direct searches, because the Sun is made of lighter elements than direct search detectors (e.g. [[xenon]] or [[germanium]]). IceCube has set better limits with the 22 string detector (about {{frac|1|4}} of the full detector) than the AMANDA limits.<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |display-authors=etal |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |year=2010 |title=Limits on a muon flux from Kaluza-Klein dark matter annihilations in the Sun from the IceCube 22-string detector |journal=[[Physical Review D]] |volume=81|issue=5 |page=057101 |arxiv=0910.4480 |bibcode=2010PhRvD..81e7101A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.81.057101 }}</ref>
===Neutrino oscillations=== IceCube can observe [[neutrino oscillation]]s from atmospheric cosmic ray showers, over a baseline across the Earth. It is most sensitive at ~25 GeV, the energy range for which the DeepCore sub-array has been optimized. DeepCore consists of 6 strings deployed in the 2009–2010 austral summer with a closer horizontal and vertical spacing. In 2014, DeepCore data was used to determine the mixing angle [[PMNS matrix|''θ''<sub>23</sub>]]<sub>.</sub> As more data is collected and IceCube can refine this measurement, it may be possible to also observe the characteristic modification of the oscillation pattern at ~15 GeV that determines the neutrino [[mass hierarchy]]. This mechanism for determining the mass hierarchy only works as the mixing angle [[PMNS matrix|''θ''<sub>13</sub>]] is large.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
===Galactic supernovae=== Despite the fact that individual neutrinos expected from supernovae have energies well below the IceCube energy cutoff, IceCube could detect a local supernova. It would appear as a detector-wide, brief, correlated rise in noise rates. The supernova would have to be relatively close (within our galaxy) to get enough neutrinos before the 1/r<sup>2</sup> distance dependence took over. IceCube is a member of the [[Supernova Early Warning System]] (SNEWS).<ref> {{cite journal |author=K. Scholberg |year=2008 |title=The SuperNova Early Warning System |journal=[[Astronomische Nachrichten]] |volume=329 |issue=3 |pages=337–339 |arxiv=0803.0531 |bibcode = 2008AN....329..337S |doi=10.1002/asna.200710934 }}</ref>
===Sterile neutrinos=== A signature of [[sterile neutrino]]s would be a distortion of the energy spectrum of atmospheric neutrinos around 1 TeV, for which IceCube is uniquely positioned to search. This signature would arise from matter effects as atmospheric neutrinos interact with the matter of the Earth.
The described detection strategy, along with its South Pole position, could allow the detector to provide the first robust experimental evidence of [[superstring theory|extra dimension]]s predicted in [[string theory]]. Many extensions of the Standard Model of particle physics, including string theory, propose a sterile neutrino; in string theory this is made from a [[closed string]]. These could leak into extra dimensions before returning, making them appear to travel faster than the speed of light. An experiment to test this may be possible in the near future.<ref> {{cite web |author=M. Chown |date=22 May 2006 |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19025521.600-at-last-a-way-to-test-time-travel.html |title=At last, a way to test time travel |website=[[New Scientist]] |accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref> Furthermore, if high energy neutrinos create microscopic [[black hole]]s (as predicted by some aspects of string theory) it would create a shower of particles, resulting in an increase of "down" neutrinos while reducing "up" neutrinos.<ref> {{cite web |date=26 January 2006 |url=http://physorg.com/news10295.html |title=South Pole Neutrino Detector Could Yield Evidences of String Theory |publisher=[[PhysOrg.com]] }}</ref>
In 2016, scientists at the IceCube detector did not find any evidence for the sterile neutrino.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/news/icy-telescope-throws-cold-water-on-sterile-neutrino-theory-1.20382#/b1|title=Icy telescope throws cold water on sterile neutrino theory|publisher=Nature|date=8 August 2016|accessdate=30 August 2018}}</ref>
==Results== The IceCube collaboration has published flux limits for neutrinos from point sources,<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |display-authors=etal |year=2009 |title=First Neutrino Point-Source Results from the 22 String Icecube Detector |journal=[[Astrophysical Journal Letters]] |volume=701 |issue= 1|pages=L47–L51 |arxiv=0905.2253 |bibcode=2009ApJ...701L..47A |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/701/1/L47 }}</ref> [[gamma-ray burst]]s,<ref> {{cite journal |last=Taboada |first=I. |date=2009 |title=Searches for neutrinos from GRBs with IceCube |journal=[[AIP Conference Series]] |volume=1133 |pages=431–433 |bibcode=2009AIPC.1133..431T |doi=10.1063/1.3155942 }}</ref> and [[neutralino]] annihilation in the Sun, with implications for WIMP-[[proton]] [[cross section (physics)|cross section]]<ref> {{cite journal |author=R. Abbasi |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |display-authors=etal |year=2009 |title=Limits on a Muon Flux from Neutralino Annihilations in the Sun with the IceCube 22-String Detector |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=102 |issue=20 |page=201302 |arxiv=0902.2460 |bibcode=2009PhRvL.102t1302A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.102.201302 |pmid=19519015 |hdl=2440/76774 }}</ref>
A shadowing effect from the Moon has been observed.<ref> {{cite web |author=E. Hand |date=3 May 2009 |title=APS 2009: The muon shadow of the Moon |url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/blog/2009/05/aps_2009_the_muon_shadow_of_th.html |website=[http://blogs.nature.com/news/blog/ In The Fields] |accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref><ref> {{cite conference |author=D. Boersma |author2=L. Gladstone |author3=A. Karle |year=2009 |title=Moon Shadow Observation by IceCube |booktitle=Proceedings of the 31st [[International Cosmic Ray Conference]] |location=Łódź, Poland |arxiv=1002.4900 |bibcode=2010arXiv1002.4900B }}</ref> Cosmic ray protons are blocked by the Moon, creating a deficit of cosmic ray shower muons in the direction of the Moon. A small (under 1%) but robust [[anisotropy]] has been observed in cosmic ray muons.<ref> {{cite conference |author1=R. Abbasi |author2=P. Desiati |author3=J.C. Díaz Vélez |year=2009 |title=Large Scale Cosmic Ray Anisotropy With IceCube |booktitle=Proceedings of the 31st [[International Cosmic Ray Conference]] |location=Łódź, Poland |arxiv=0907.0498 |bibcode=2009arXiv0907.0498A }}</ref><!--suggested an effect similar to the one observed by the [[Milagro (experiment)|Milagro gamma-ray observatory]].-->
A pair of high energy neutrinos were detected in 2013.<ref> {{cite journal |author1=IceCube Collaboration |year=1242 |title=Evidence for High-Energy Extraterrestrial Neutrinos at the IceCube Detector |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=342 |issue=6161 |pages=1242856 |arxiv=1311.5238 |bibcode=2013Sci...342E...1I |doi=10.1126/science.1242856 |pmid=24264993 }}</ref> Possibly of astrophysical origin, they were in the peta-electron volt range, making them the highest energy neutrinos discovered to date. The pair were nicknamed [[Bert and Ernie|"Bert" and "Ernie"]], after characters from the [[Sesame Street]] TV show.<ref> {{cite web |author=G. Devorsky |date=26 April 2013 |title=Neutrinos From Another Galaxy Have Been Discovered in Antarctica |url=http://io9.com/neutrinos-from-another-galaxy-have-been-discovered-in-a-482689596 |publisher=i09.com |accessdate=2013-12-29 }}</ref> An even more energetic neutrino was discovered in 2013<ref> {{cite journal |author=M. G. Aartsen |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |display-authors=etal |year=2014 |title=Observation of High-Energy Astrophysical Neutrinos in Three Years of IceCube Data |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=113 |issue=10 |page=101101 |arxiv=1405.5303 |bibcode=2014PhRvL.113j1101A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.101101 |pmid=25238345 }}</ref> and given the name "[[Big Bird]]".<ref> {{cite web |title=Big Bird joins Bert and Ernie |url=http://antarcticaneutrinos.blogspot.com/2013/11/big-bird-joins-bert-and-ernie.html }}</ref>
IceCube measured 10 to 100 GeV atmospheric muon neutrino disappearance in 2014 {{clarify|date=August 2018}}, using 3 years of data taken May 2011 to April 2014 including DeepCore,<ref> {{Cite journal |author=IceCube Collaboration |year=2015 |title=Determining neutrino oscillation parameters from atmospheric muon neutrino disappearance with three years of IceCube DeepCore data |journal=[[Physical Review D]] |volume=91 |issue=7 |pages=072004 |arxiv=1410.7227 |bibcode=2015PhRvD..91g2004A |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.91.072004 }}</ref> determining [[neutrino oscillation]] parameters ∆m<sup>2</sup><sub>32</sub> = {{val|2.72|+0.19|−0.20}} × 10<sup>−3</sup>eV<sup>2</sup> and sin<sup>2</sup>(θ<sub>23</sub>) = {{val|0.53|+0.09|−0.12}} (normal mass hierarchy), comparable to other results.
In July 2018, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory announced that they have traced an extremely-high-energy neutrino that hit their detector in September 2017 back to its point of origin in the [[blazar]] [[TXS 0506 +056]] located 3.7 billion [[light-year|light-years]] away in the direction of the constellation [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Multimessenger observations of a flaring blazar coincident with high-energy neutrino IceCube-170922A |collaboration=The IceCube Collaboration, Fermi-LAT, MAGIC, AGILE, ASAS-SN, HAWC, H.E.S.S., INTEGRAL, Kanata, Kiso, Kapteyn, Liverpool Telescope, Subaru, Swift/NuSTAR, VERITAS, VLA/17B-403 teams|last=Aartsen |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |date=12 July 2018 |volume=361 |issue=6398 |page=eaat1378 |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/361/6398/eaat1378 |doi=10.1126/science.aat1378|pmid=30002226|arxiv=1807.08816 |bibcode=2018Sci...361.1378I }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Neutrino emission from the direction of the blazar TXS 0506+056 prior to the IceCube-170922A alert |collaboration=IceCube Collaboration |last=Aartsen |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |date=12 July 2018 |volume=361 |issue=6398 |pages=147–151 |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/361/6398/147 |doi=10.1126/science.aat2890|pmid=30002248 |bibcode=2018Sci...361..147I |arxiv=1807.08794 }}</ref> This is the first time that a [[neutrino detector]] has been used to locate an object in space and indicates that a source of [[cosmic rays]] has been identified.<ref name="NYT-20180712">{{cite news |last=Overbye |first=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis Overbye |title=It Came From a Black Hole, and Landed in Antarctica - For the first time, astronomers followed cosmic neutrinos into the fire-spitting heart of a supermassive blazar. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/12/science/space-neutrinos-blazar.html |date=12 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=13 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Neutrino that struck Antarctica traced to galaxy 3.7bn light years away |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/jul/12/neutrino-that-struck-antarctica-traced-to-galaxy-37bn-light-years-away |website=The Guardian |date=12 July 2018 |accessdate=12 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Source of cosmic 'ghost' particle revealed |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-44786125y |website=BBC |date=12 July 2018 |accessdate=12 July 2018 }}</ref>
== See also == *[[Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array]] *[[Radio Ice Cerenkov Experiment]] *[[ANTARES (telescope)|ANTARES]] and [[KM3NeT]], similar neutrino telescopes using deep-sea water instead of ice.

{{expert-subject|1=Genetics|date=December 2011}} {{see also|Outline of genetics}} '''[[Genetics]]''' (from [[Ancient Greek]] {{lang|grc|γενετικός}} ''{{lang|grc-Latn|genetikos}}'', “genite” and that from {{lang|grc|γένεσις}} ''{{lang|grc-Latn|genesis}}'', “origin”<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3D%2321880 Genetikos, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, "A Greek-English Lexicon", at Perseus]</ref><ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3D%2321873 Genesis, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, "A Greek-Eng Lexon", at Perseus]</ref><ref>[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=Genetic&searchmode=none Online Etymology Dictionary]</ref>), a discipline of [[biology]], is the [[science]] of [[heredity]] and [[Genetic variation|variation]] in living [[organism]]s.<ref>Griffiths et al. (2000), [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=iga.section.60 Chapter 1 (Genetics and the Organism): Introduction]</ref>
Articles (arranged alphabetically) related to [[genetics]] include: __NOTOC__

revision.comment: /* 1I/2017 U1 (ʻOumuamua) */ added relevant text
revision.text:
{{short description|Astronomical object not gravitationally bound to a star}} {{multiple image | direction = vertical | align = right | width = 290 | image1 = Oumuamua-solar system 2018.png | image2 = Hyakutake Color.jpg | caption1 = Path of the hyperbolic, extrasolar object [[ʻOumuamua]], the first confirmed interstellar object, discovered in 2017 | caption2 = [[Comet Hyakutake]] (C/1996 B2) might be an interstellar object captured by the Solar System. Photographed at its closest approach to Earth on 25 March 1996. The streaks in the background are stars. }}
An '''interstellar object''' is a body, other than a [[star]] or [[Substellar object|substar]], that is located in [[interstellar space]] and is not [[gravitationally bound]] to a star. The term can also be applied to objects that are on an interstellar trajectory but are temporarily passing close to a star, such as certain [[asteroid]]s and [[comet]]s (including [[exocomet]]s<ref name="Valtonen">{{cite journal| last = Valtonen| first = Mauri J.| author2 = Jia-Qing Zheng | author3 = Seppo Mikkola| title = Origin of oort cloud comets in the interstellar space| journal = Celestial Mechanics and Dynamical Astronomy| volume = 54| issue = 1–3| pages = 37–48| date = March 1992| url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/g43v16167077453u/| doi = 10.1007/BF00049542| accessdate = 2008-12-30|bibcode = 1992CeMDA..54...37V }}</ref><ref name="Francis">{{cite journal| last = Francis| first = Paul J.| date = 2005-12-20| title = The Demographics of Long-Period Comets| journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 635| issue = 2| pages = 1348–1361| doi = 10.1086/497684| bibcode = 2005ApJ...635.1348F | url = http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/0004-637X/635/2/1348/62880.web.pdf?request-id=035fe065-820f-4c15-b74e-1cb158b2a41d| accessdate = 2009-01-03|arxiv = astro-ph/0509074 }}</ref>).
Due to present observational difficulties, an interstellar object can usually only be detected if it passes through the [[Solar System]], where it can be distinguished by its strongly [[hyperbolic trajectory]], indicating that it is not gravitationally bound to the Sun.<ref name=Francis/><ref name="hyperbolics">{{cite journal |last1=de la Fuente Marcos |first1=Carlos |last2=de la Fuente Marcos |first2=Raúl |last3=Aarseth |first3=Sverre J. |date=6 February 2018 |title=Where the Solar system meets the solar neighbourhood: patterns in the distribution of radiants of observed hyperbolic minor bodies |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society Letters |volume= 476 |issue= 1 |pages= L1–L5 |arxiv=1802.00778 |bibcode=2018MNRAS.476L...1D |doi=10.1093/mnrasl/sly019 |url= https://academic.oup.com/mnrasl/article-abstract/476/1/L1/4840245 }}</ref> In contrast, gravitationally bound objects follow [[elliptic orbit]]s around the Sun, like most asteroids, comets, and objects in the [[Oort cloud]].
It is possible for objects orbiting a star to be ejected due to interaction with a third massive body, thereby becoming interstellar objects. Such a process was initiated in early 1980s when [[C/1980 E1]], initially gravitationally bound to the Sun, passed near Jupiter and was accelerated sufficiently to reach escape velocity from the Solar System. This changed its orbit from elliptical to hyperbolic and made it the most eccentric known object at the time, with an [[Orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 1.057.<ref name="jpldata">{{cite web |type=1986-12-02 last obs |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: C/1980 E1 (Bowell) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=1980%20E1 |accessdate=2010-01-08}}</ref> It is headed for interstellar space.
The first discovered, and to date only known, interstellar object is [[ʻOumuamua]] (1I/ʻOumuamua, previously called C/2017 U1 and A/2017 U1). The object has an orbital eccentricity of about 1.20.
Recent research suggests that asteroid [[(514107) 2015 BZ509]] may be a former interstellar object, captured some 4.5 billion years ago, as evidenced by its co-orbital motion with Jupiter and its retrograde orbit around the Sun.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/05/asteroid-came-another-solar-system-and-it-s-here-stay|title=This asteroid came from another solar system—and it’s here to stay|publisher=Science}}</ref>
==Nomenclature== With the first discovery of an interstellar object, the IAU has proposed a new series of small-body designations for interstellar objects, the ''I numbers,'' similar to the comet numbering system. The [[Minor Planet Center]] will assign the numbers. Provisional designations for interstellar objects will be handled using the C/ or A/ prefix, (comet or asteroid) as appropriate.<ref>{{cite web|title=MPEC 2017-V17 : NEW DESIGNATION SCHEME FOR INTERSTELLAR OBJECTS|url=https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K17/K17V17.html|publisher= minor planet center|date=6 November 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== [[File:96P 20070403 000500 HI1A.png|thumb|left|[[Machholz 1|Comet Machholz 1 (96P/Machholz)]] as viewed by [[STEREO|STEREO-A]] (April 2007)]] [[File:Solar_apex.png|thumb|The [[Solar apex]], the direction of the sun's motion in the [[Local Standard of Rest]], is towards a point between [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]] and [[Lyra]]. [[right ascension|R.A.]] 18h28m and [[declination|Dec.]] 30°N (Epoch J2000.0)]]
Current models of [[Oort cloud]] formation predict that more comets are ejected into interstellar space than are retained in the Oort cloud, with estimates varying from 3 to 100 times as many.<ref name=Francis/> Other simulations suggest that 90–99% of comets are ejected.<ref name="Choi">{{cite web | last = Choi | first = Charles Q. | title = The Enduring Mysteries of Comets | publisher = Space.com | url = http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/071224-mm-comet-mysteries.html | date = 2007-12-24 | accessdate = 2008-12-30}}</ref> There is no reason to believe comets formed in other star systems would not be similarly scattered.<ref name=Valtonen />
If interstellar comets exist, they must occasionally pass through the inner [[Solar System]].<ref name=Valtonen /> They would approach the Solar System with random velocities, mostly from the direction of the constellation [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]] because the Solar System is moving in that direction, called the [[solar apex]].<ref name=Struve>{{cite book | last = Struve | first = Otto | authorlink = Otto Struve | author2 = Lynds, Beverly | author3 = Pillans, Helen | title = Elementary Astronomy | publisher = Oxford University Press | date = 1959 | location = New York | pages = 150 }}</ref> Until the discovery of [['Oumuamua]], the fact that no comet with a speed greater than the [[Sun]]'s escape velocity<ref name=MacRobert /> had been observed was used to place upper limits to their density in interstellar space. A paper by Torbett indicated that the density was no more than 10<sup>13</sup> (10 [[Orders of magnitude (numbers)#1012|trillion]]) comets per cubic [[parsec]].<ref name="Torbett">{{cite journal| last = Torbett| first = M. V.| title = Capture of 20 km/s approach velocity interstellar comets by three-body interactions in the planetary system| journal = Astronomical Journal| volume = 92| pages = 171–175| date = July 1986| bibcode = 1986AJ.....92..171T| doi = 10.1086/114148}}</ref> Other analyses, of data from [[LINEAR]], set the upper limit at 4.5{{e|−4}}/[[Astronomical unit|AU]]<sup>3</sup>, or 10<sup>12</sup> (1 trillion) comets per cubic [[parsec]].<ref name=Francis/> A more recent estimate by [[David C. Jewitt]] and colleagues, following the detection of [['Oumuamua]], predicts that "The steady-state population of similar, ~100 m scale interstellar objects inside the orbit of Neptune is ~1{{e|4}}, each with a residence time of ~10 years."<ref name="Jewitt2017">{{cite journal|doi=10.3847/2041-8213/aa9b2f|title=Interstellar Interloper 1I/2017 U1: Observations from the NOT and WIYN Telescopes|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=850|issue=2|pages=L36|year=2017|last1=Jewitt|first1=David|last2=Luu|first2=Jane|last3=Rajagopal|first3=Jayadev|last4=Kotulla|first4=Ralf|last5=Ridgway|first5=Susan|last6=Liu|first6=Wilson|last7=Augusteijn|first7=Thomas|bibcode=2017ApJ...850L..36J|arxiv=1711.05687}}</ref>
An interstellar comet can probably, on rare occasions, be captured into a [[heliocentric]] orbit while passing through the [[Solar System]]. Computer simulations show that [[Jupiter]] is the only planet massive enough to capture one, and that this can be expected to occur once every sixty million years.<ref name=Torbett /> Comets [[Machholz 1]] and [[Comet Hyakutake|Hyakutake C/1996 B2]] are possible examples of such comets. They have atypical chemical makeups for comets in the Solar System.<ref name="MacRobert">{{cite news | last = MacRobert| first = Alan| title = A Very Oddball Comet| publisher = Sky & Telescope| date = 2008-12-02| url = http://www.skyandtelescope.com/news/35379224.html| accessdate = 2010-03-26}}</ref><ref name="science">{{cite journal | last=Mumma | first=M.J. | author2 = Disanti, M.A. | author3 = dello Russo, N. | author4 = Fomenkova, M. | author5 = Magee-Sauer, K. | author6 = Kaminski, C.D. | author7 = D.X. Xie | title=Detection of Abundant Ethane and Methane, Along with Carbon Monoxide and Water, in Comet C/1996 B2 Hyakutake: Evidence for Interstellar Origin | journal=Science | date=1996 | volume=272 | pages=1310–1314 | bibcode = 1996Sci...272.1310M | doi=10.1126/science.272.5266.1310 | pmid=8650540 | issue=5266}}</ref>
==1I/2017 U1 (ʻOumuamua)== {{main|ʻOumuamua}} [[File:PIA22357-InterstellarObject-'Oumuamua-ExitsSolarSystem.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Interstellar comet 'Oumuamua, the first confirmed interstellar object,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7006|title=Solar System's First Interstellar Visitor Dazzles Scientists|website=NASA/JPL|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref> exiting the solar system (artist concept)</center>]] <!---[[File:Artist's impression of ʻOumuamua.jpg|thumb|Artist's impression of ʻOumuamua, the first confirmed interstellar asteroid<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7006|title=Solar System's First Interstellar Visitor Dazzles Scientists|website=NASA/JPL|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref>]]---> A dim object was discovered on October 19, 2017 by the [[Pan-STARRS]] telescope, at an apparent magnitude of 20. The observations showed that it follows a strongly hyperbolic trajectory around the Sun at a speed greater than the solar escape velocity, in turn meaning that it is not gravitationally bound to the Solar System and likely to be an interstellar object.<ref name="C2017U1discovery">{{cite web|title=MPEC 2017-U181: COMET C/2017 U1 (PANSTARRS)|url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K17/K17UI1.html|website=Minor Planet Center|publisher=International Astronomical Union|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref> It was initially named C/2017 U1 because it was assumed to be a comet, and was renamed to A/2017 U1 after no cometary activity was found on October 25.<ref name="A2017U1announcement">{{cite web|author=K. Meech|title=Minor Planet Electronic Circular MPEC 2017-U183: A/2017 U1|url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K17/K17UI3.html|website=Minor Planet Center|publisher=[[International Astronomical Union]]|date=25 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="A2017U1announcement"/><ref>{{cite news|title=We May Just Have Found An Object That Originated From Outside Our Solar System|url=http://www.iflscience.com/space/the-first-likely-interstellar-asteroid-has-been-found-and-it-might-be-from-vega/|publisher=[[Iflscience|IFLScience]]|date=October 26, 2017}}</ref> After its interstellar nature was confirmed, it was renamed to 1I/ʻOumuamua – '1' because it is the first such object to be discovered, 'I' for interstellar, and "‘Oumuamua" is a Hawaiian word meaning "a messenger from afar arriving first".<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2017/aloha-oumuamua-interstellar-asteroid-gets-hawaiian-name-first-kind/|title=Aloha, ‘Oumuamua! Scientists confirm that interstellar asteroid is a cosmic oddball|publisher=GeekWire|date=20 November 2017}}</ref>
The lack of [[Coma (cometary)|cometary activity]] from ʻOumuamua suggests an origin from the inner regions of whatever stellar system it came from, losing all surface volatiles within the [[Frost line (astrophysics)|frost line]], much like the rocky asteroids, [[extinct comets]] and [[damocloids]] we know from our Solar System. This is only a suggestion, as ʻOumuamua might very well have lost all surface volatiles to eons of [[cosmic radiation]] exposure in interstellar space, developing a thick crust layer after it was expelled from its parent system.
ʻOumuamua has an [[Orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 1.199, which is the highest eccentricity ever observed for any object in the Solar System by a wide margin.
In September 2018, astronomers described several possible home [[star system]]s from which 'Oumuamua, that was detected passing through the Solar System in October 2017, may have begun its interstellar journey.<ref name="ARX-20180924">{{Cite arxiv |eprint = 1809.09009|last1 = Feng|first1 = Fabo|title = Plausible home stars of the interstellar object 'Oumuamua found in Gaia DR2|last2 = Jones|first2 = Hugh R. A.|class = astro-ph.EP|year = 2018}}</ref><ref>[https://www.space.com/41928-where-did-oumuamua-come-from.html 'Oumuamua Isn't from Our Solar System. Now We May Know Which Star It Came From]</ref>
In November 2018, Harvard astronomers reported that there should be hundreds of 'Oumuamua-size interstellar objects in the Solar System, based on calculated orbital characteristics, and presented several known examples, namely, [[2011 SP25]], [[2017 RR2]], [[2017 SV13]], and [[2018 TL6]].<ref name=MNRAS-20181129">{{cite journal |last1=Siraj |first1=Amir |last2=Loeb |first2=Abraham |title=Identifying Interstellar Objects Trapped in the Solar System through Their Orbital Parameters |url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/1811.09632.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=29 November 2018 |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=000 |pages=1-5 |accessdate=1 December 2018 }}</ref> These are all orbiting the sun, but with unusual orbits, and are assumed to have been trapped at some occasion.
== See also == * {{annotated link|Exocomet}} * {{annotated link|Hyperbolic asteroid}} * {{annotated link|List of Solar System objects by greatest aphelion}} * {{annotated link|Masks (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|Masks}}, Star Trek episode about a possible rogue comet * {{annotated link|Rogue planet}} * [[Project Lyra]], study of probe missions to catch 'Oumuamua and similar objects

revision.comment: not an orphan
revision.text:
An '''intracule''' is a [[quantum mechanics|quantum mechanical]] mathematical function for the two electron density which depends not upon the absolute values of position or momentum but rather upon their relative values. Its use is leading to new methods in [[physics]] and [[computational chemistry]] to investigate the [[electronic structure]] of molecules and solids. These methods are a development of [[Density functional theory]] (DFT), but with the two electron density replacing the one electron density.
==References== P. M. W. Gill, D. L. Crittenden, D. P. O'Neill and N. A. Besley, ''A family of intracules, a conjecture and the electron correlation problem'', [[Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics]], 2006, '''8''', 15 - 25.
[[Category:Computational chemistry]] [[Category:Theoretical chemistry]] [[Category:Computational science]]
{{physics-stub}}

[[File:Purcell portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|200px|Engraved portrait of Purcell by [[Robert White (engraver)|R. White]] after [[John Closterman|Closterman]], from ''[[Orpheus Britannicus]]'']] This is a '''list of [[musical composition]]s by [[Henry Purcell]]'''.
==By Z number== Pieces listed according to the [[Franklin B. Zimmerman|Zimmerman]] catalogue.
===Anthems [Z 1–65]=== *'''Z 1''', Verse Anthem, "Awake, put on thy strength" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 2''', Verse Anthem, "Behold, I bring you glad tidings" (1687) *'''Z 3''', Verse Anthem, "Behold now, praise the Lord" (c. 1680) *'''Z 4''', Verse Anthem, "Be merciful unto me" (before 1683) *'''Z 5''', Verse Anthem, "Blessed are they that fear the Lord" (1688) *'''Z 6''', Verse Anthem, "Blessed be the Lord my strength" (before 1679) *'''Z 7''', Verse Anthem, "Blessed is he that considereth the poor" (c. 1688) *'''Z 8''', Verse Anthem, "Blessed is he whose unrighteousness is forgiven" (c. 1680–92) *'''Z 9''', Verse Anthem, "Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord" (c. 1688) *'''Z 10''', Full Anthem, "Blow up the trumpet in Sion" (before 1679) *'''Z 11''', Verse Anthem, "Bow down thine ear, O Lord" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 12''', Verse Anthem, "Give sentence with me, O Lord" (before 1681) *'''Z 13''', Verse Anthem, "Hear me, O Lord, and that soon" (c. 1680–82) – [There are 2 arrangements of this piece, Z 13A and Z 13B respectively] *'''Z 14''', Verse Anthem, "Hear my prayer, O God" (before 1683) *'''Z 15''', Full Anthem, "[[Hear my prayer, O Lord (Purcell)|Hear my prayer, O Lord]]" (before 1683) *'''Z 16''', Verse Anthem, "In thee, O Lord, do I put my trust" (c. 1682) *'''Z 17''', Full Anthem, "In the midst of life" (before 1682) – [There are 2 arrangements of this piece, Z 17A and Z 17B respectively] *'''Z 18''', Verse Anthem, "It is a good thing to give thanks" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 19''', Verse Anthem, "I was glad when they said unto me" (c. 1682–83) *'''Z 20''', Verse Anthem, "I will give thanks unto Thee, O Lord" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 21''', Verse Anthem, "I will give thanks unto the Lord" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 22''', Full Anthem, "I will sing unto the Lord" (before 1679) *'''Z 23''', Verse Anthem, "Let God arise" (before 1679) *'''Z 24''', Verse Anthem, "Let mine eyes run down with tears" (c. 1682) *'''Z 25''', Full Anthem, "Lord, how long wilt Thou be angry?" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 26''', Verse Anthem, "Lord, who can tell how oft he offendeth?" (c. 1677) *'''Z 27''', Full Anthem, "Man that is born of woman" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 28''', Verse Anthem, "My beloved spake" (before 1677) *'''Z 29''', Verse Anthem, "My heart is fixed, O God" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 30''', Verse Anthem, "My heart is inditing" (1685) *'''Z 31''', Verse Anthem, "My song shall be always" (1690) *'''Z 32''', Verse Anthem, "O consider my adversity" (Unknown) *'''Z 33''', Verse Anthem, "O give thanks unto the Lord" (1693) *'''Z 34''', Full Anthem, "O God, the king of glory" (before 1679) *'''Z 35''', Full Anthem, "O God, thou art my god" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 36''', Full Anthem, "O God, thou has cast us out" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 37''', Full Anthem, "O Lord God of hosts" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 38''', Verse Anthem, "O Lord, grant the King a long life" (1685) *'''Z 39''', Verse Anthem, "O Lord, our governor" (before 1679) *'''Z 40''', Verse Anthem, "O Lord, rebuke me not" (Unknown) *'''Z 41''', Verse Anthem, "O Lord, Thou art my God" (c. 1680–82) *'''Z 42''', Verse Anthem, "O praise God in his holiness" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 43''', Verse Anthem, "O praise the Lord, all ye heathen" (before 1681) *'''Z 44''', Verse Anthem, "O sing unto the Lord" (1688) *'''Z 45''', Verse Anthem, "Out of the deep have I called" (c. 1680) *'''Z 46''', Verse Anthem, "Praise the Lord, O Jerusalem" (1689) – [There is another Z 46, a fragment of a Verse Anthem, "Praise the Lord, ye servants"] *'''Z 47''', Verse Anthem, "Praise the Lord, O my soul, and all that is within me" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 48''', Verse Anthem, "Praise the Lord, O my soul, O Lord my God" (1687) *'''Z 49''', Verse Anthem, "Rejoice in the Lord alway" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 50''', Full Anthem, "[[Remember not, Lord, our offences]]" (c. 1679–82) *'''Z 51''', Full Anthem, "Save me, O God" (before 1681) *'''Z 52''', Verse Anthem, "Sing unto God" (1687) *'''Z 53''', Verse Anthem, "The Lord is king, be the people never so impatient" (Unknown) *'''Z 54''', Verse Anthem, "The Lord is King, the earth may be glad [thereof]" (1688) *'''Z 55''', Verse Anthem, "The Lord is my light" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 56''', Verse Anthem, "The way of God is an undefiled way" (1694) *'''Z 57''', Verse Anthem, "They that go down to the sea in ships" (1685) *'''Z 58''', Verse Anthem, "Thou know'st, Lord, the secrets of our hearts" (1687) – [There are 2 arrangements of this piece, Z 58A Z 58B, and a further Z 58C, which is a Full Anthem] *'''Z 59''', Full Anthem, "Thy righteousness, O God, is very high" (Unknown) *'''Z 60''', Verse Anthem, "Thy way, O God, is holy" (1687) *'''Z 61''', Verse Anthem, "Thy word is a lantern unto my feet" (Unknown) *'''Z 62''', Verse Anthem, "Turn thou us, O good Lord" (Unknown) *'''Z 63''', Verse Anthem, "Unto Thee will I cry" (c. 1682–85) *'''Z 64''', Verse Anthem, "Who hath believed our report?" (c. 1679–80) *'''Z 65''', Verse Anthem, "Why do the heathen so furiously rage together?" (c. 1682–85)
===Hymns and sacred songs [Z 101–200]=== *'''Z 101''', Catch, "Joy, mirth, triumphs I do defy" (Unknown) – [Possibly originally an Alleluia] *'''Z 103''', Canon, "Gloria Patri et Filio" (c. 1680) *'''Z 104''', Canon, "Gloria Patri et Filio" – Canon 3 in 1 (c. 1680) *'''Z 105''', Canon, "Gloria Patri et Filio" – Canon 4 in 1 per arsin et thesin (c. 1680) *'''Z 106''', Canon, "Gloria Patri et Filio" – Canon 4 in 1 (c. 1680) *'''Z 107''', Canon, "Gloria Patri et Filio" – Canon 7 in 1 at the unison (Unknown) *'''Z 108''', Canon, "Laudate Dominum" – Canon 3 in 1 (Unknown) *'''Z 109''', Canon, "Miserere mei" – Canon 4 in 2 (published 1687) *'''Z 120''', Chant in A minor (Unknown) – [Z 120 through Z 125 are of doubtful provenance] *'''Z 121''', Chant in G major (Unknown) *'''Z 122''', Chant in G major (Unknown) *'''Z 123''', Chant in D minor (Unknown) *'''Z 124''', Chant in G major (Unknown) *'''Z 125''', Burford psalm-tune in G minor (Unknown) *'''Z 130''', Hymn, "Ah! few and full of sorrow" (c. 1680) *'''Z 131''', Hymn, "Beati omnes [qui timent Dominum]" (c. 1680) *'''Z 132''', Hymn, "Early, O Lord, my fainting soul" (c. 1680) *'''Z 133''', Hymn, "Hear me, O Lord, the great support" (1680–82) *'''Z 134''', Hymn, "In guilty night" (published 1693) *'''Z 135''', Hymn, "Jehova, quam multi sunt [hestes]" (c. 1680) *'''Z 136''', Hymn, "Lord, I can suffer thy rebukes" (c. 1680) *'''Z 137''', Hymn, "Lord, not to us, but to thy name" (c. 1680) *'''Z 138''', Hymn, "O all ye people, clap your hands" (c. 1680) *'''Z 139''', Hymn, "O happy man that fears the Lord" (Unknown) *'''Z 140''', Hymn, "O, I'm sick of life" (c. 1680) *'''Z 141''', Hymn, "O Lord our governor" (c. 1680) *'''Z 142''', Hymn, "Plung'd in the confines of despair" (c. 1680) *'''Z 143''', Hymn, "Since God, so tender a regard" (c. 1680) *'''Z 144''', Hymn, "When on my sickbed I languish" (c. 1680) *'''Z 181''', Hymn, "Awake, and with attention hear" (published 1681) *'''Z 182''', Hymn, "Awake, ye dead" (published 1693) *'''Z 183''', Hymn, "Begin the song, and strike the living lyre" (published 1681) *'''Z 184''', Hymn, "Close thine eyes and sleep secure" (published 1688) *'''Z 185''', Hymn, "Full of wrath his threatening breath" (Unknown) *'''Z 186''', Hymn, "Great God and just" (published 1688) *'''Z 187''', Hymn, "Hosanna to the highest" (Unknown) *'''Z 188''', Hymn, "How have I strayed" (published 1688) *'''Z 189''', Hymn, "How long, great God?" (published 1688) *'''Z 190''', Hymn, "In the black dismal dungeon of despair" (published 1688) *'''Z 191''', Hymn, "Let the night perish" (published 1688) *'''Z 192''', Hymn, "Lord, what is man?" (published 1693) *'''Z 193''', Hymn, "Now that the sun hath veiled his light" (published 1688) *'''Z 195''', Hymn, "Sleep, Adam[, sleep and take thy rest]" (published 1688) *'''Z 196''', Hymn, "Tell me, some pitying angel" (published 1693) *'''Z 197''', Hymn, "The earth trembled" (published 1688) *'''Z 198''', Hymn, "Thou wakeful shepherd" (published 1688) *'''Z 199''', Hymn, "We sing to him, whose wisdom form'd the ear" (published 1688) *'''Z 200''', Hymn, "With sick and famish'd eyes" (published 1688)
===Services [Z 230–232]=== *'''Z 230/1''', Morning Service, "Te Deum Laudamus in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/2''', Morning Service, "Benedictus in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/3''', Morning Service, "Benedicite Omnia Opera in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/4''', Morning Service, "Jubilate Deo in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/5''', Communion Service, "Kyrie Eleison in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/6''', Communion Service, "Nicene Creed in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/7''', Evening Service, "Magnificat in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/8''', Evening Service, "Nunc dimittis in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/9''', Evening Service, "Cantate Domino in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 230/10''', Evening Service, "Deus misereator in B-flat major" (before 1682) *'''Z 231''', Evening Service, "Magnificat and Nunc dimittis in G minor" (Unknown) *'''Z 232''', Morning Service, "Te Deum and Jubilate Deo in D major" (1694)
===Catches [Z 240–292]=== *'''Z 240''', [[Catch (music)|Catch]], "A health to the nut-brown lass" (1685) *'''Z 241''', Catch, "An ape, a lion, a fox and an ass" (1686) *'''Z 242''', Catch, "As Roger last night to Jenny lay close" (Unknown) *'''Z 243''', Catch, "Bring the bowl and cool Nantz" (1693–94) *'''Z 244''', Catch, "Call for the reckoning" (Unknown) *'''Z 245''', Catch, "Come let us drink" (Unknown) *'''Z 246''', Catch, "Come my hearts, play your parts" (1685) *'''Z 247''', Catch, "Down, down with Bacchus" (1693) *'''Z 248''', Catch, "Drink on till night be spent" (1686) *'''Z 249''', Catch, "Full bags, a brisk bottle" (1686) *'''Z 250''', Catch, "God save our sovereign Charles" (1685) *'''Z 251''', Catch, "Great Apollo and Bacchus" (Unknown) *'''Z 252''', Catch, "Here's a health, pray let it pass" (Unknown) *'''Z 253''', Catch, "Here's that will challenge all the fair" (1680) *'''Z 254''', Catch, "He that drinks is immortal" (1686) *'''Z 255''', Catch, "If all be true that I do think" (1689) *'''Z 256''', Catch, "I gave her cakes and I gave her ale" (1690) *'''Z 257''', Catch, "Is Charleroy's siege come too?" (1685) *'''Z 289''', Catch, "Wine in a morning makes us frolic and gay" (1686) *'''Z 290''', Catch, "Would you know how we meet" (1685) *'''Z 291''', Catch, "Young Colin cleaving of a beam" (1691) *'''Z 292''', Catch, "Young John the gard'ner" (1683)

revision.text:
{{merge to|Samdani Art Foundation|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Nadia Samdani | image = Nadia Samdani.jpg | image_size = 200px | occupation = Art collector, philanthropist | nationality = British-Bangladeshi }}
'''Nadia Samdani''' (born 12 December 1981) is a British-born Bangladeshi philanthropist, art patron and collector. She is the co-founder and president of the Samdani Art Foundation, and director of the Dhaka Art Summit. She is also the director of Golden Harvest Group, a leading Bangladeshi conglomerate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenharvestbd.com/managemet/|title=Directors Profile – Golden Harvest|website=www.goldenharvestbd.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/our-team/|title=OUR TEAM|website=Samdani Art Foundation}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == Nadia and her husband Rajeeb Samdani were donors for the 56th International Biennale di Venezia in 2015, supporting projects by [[Naeem Mohaiemen]] and Raqs Media Collective in the main Biennale exhibition: All the World's Futures. They have also supported [[Naeem Mohaiemen]]'s first European Solo exhibition "Prisoners of Shothik Itihash" at [[Kunsthalle Basel]], curated by [[Adam Szymczyk]] in 2014, and Bangladeshi-British artist Rana Begum's first major institutional solo exhibition at The Parasol Unit in 2016. The support took place under their non-profit engagement, Samdani Art Foundation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Show me the money|last=Gareth|first=Harris|date=2 May 2015|newspaper=Financial Times|quote=The Dhaka-based Samdani Art Foundation, for instance, is sponsoring the Bangladeshi artist Naeem Mohaiemen and Raqs Media Collective in the main biennale exhibition ( All the World's Futures )}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://newagebd.net/108205/saf-to-promote-2-projects-at-venice-biennale/|title=New Age – SAF to promote 2 projects at Venice biennale|date=3 April 2015|publisher=Newagebd.net|accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kunsthallebasel.ch/en/exhibition/prisoners-of-shothik-itihash/|title=Prisoners of Shothik Itihash • Kunsthalle Basel|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://parasol-unit.org/whats-on/rana-begum-space/|title=Rana Begum: The Space Between - Parasol unit|publisher=}}</ref>
Nadia Samdani founded the [[Samdani Art Foundation]] in 2011 along with her husband Rajeeb Samdani. Nadia acts as the President of the foundation, which supports the work of Bangladeshi and South Asian contemporary artists and architects to increase their international exposure. As part of the initiative, the foundation runs the bi-annual Samdani Art and Architecture Awards which bring to light, the work of emerging Bangladeshi contemporary artists and architects.The Foundations other on-going initiatives include the Samdani Artist-Led Initiatives Forum and Samdani Seminars.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frieze.com/article/how-see-somewhere-else-4th-dhaka-art-summit|title=How to See from Somewhere Else – the 4th Dhaka Art Summit|website=frieze.com}}</ref><ref>https://independent-collectors.com/interviews/nadia-rajeeb-samdani-dhaka-art-summit/ Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/news-flash/samdani-architecture-award-winner-announced-1464085|title=Samdani Architecture Award winner announced|date=19 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/news/news_5_feb_18_mizanur_rahman_chowdhury_wins_samdani_art_award/|title=Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury wins Samdani Art Award / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theartling.com/en/artzine/2018/02/05/re-examinations-on-the-function-of-art-dhaka-art-summit-2018/|title=Re-Examinations on the Function of Art: Dhaka Art Summit 2018 - The Artling|website=The Artling}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2015/04/09/samdani-seminars-art-in-body-steps|title=Samdani Seminars: Art in body steps|date=9 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Nadia Samdani with the President of Switzerland Mr. Alain Berset at the Dhaka Art Summit 2018.jpg|thumb|Mr. Alain Berset, the President of Switzerland visited Dhaka Art Summit on 7th February 2018 during his visit to Bangladesh.]] Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani have announced to open Srihatta—Samdani Art Centre and Sculpture Park in late 2018. The centre is being designed by Kashef Mahboob Chowdhury, who won the [[Aga Khan Award for Architecture|Aga Khan Award]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abinlot/2017/05/11/srihatta-samdani-art-centre-and-sculpture-park-to-open-late-2018-in-bangladesh/#7005cee54578|title=Srihatta: Samdani Art Centre And Sculpture Park To Open Late 2018 In Bangladesh|first=Ann|last=Binlot|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/05/12/samdani-art-foundation-unveils-plans-and-announces-programming-for-first-permanent-space/|title=Samdani Art Foundation Unveils Plans for First Permanent Space|first=Sarah|last=Douglas|date=12 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://culture360.asef.org/news-events/srihatta-samdani-art-centre-takes-shape-bangladesh|title=Srihatta-Samdani Art Centre takes shape in Bangladesh - ASEF culture360|website=culture360.asef.org}}</ref>
=== Dhaka Art Summit === Dhaka Art Summit is the most successful initiative Nadia Samdani has established in 2012. The Summit takes place every two years at the Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy in collaboration with the Ministry of Cultural Affairs, People's Republic of Bangladesh and is said to be the largest international event for South Asian art. The 4th edition of the Summit took place between 2 and 10 February 2018, receiving a footfall of 317,000, including over 1,200 international visitors and the President of Switzerland, Mr. Alain Berset.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/800895/bangladeshs-first-art-summit-ends-on-a-high|title=Bangladesh’s First Art Summit Ends on a High - Artinfo|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/beyond-business/collector-s-corner-112030300055_1.html|title=Collector's corner|first=Gargi|last=Gupta|date=3 March 2012|publisher=|via=Business Standard}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/art/dhaka-art-summit-lauds-bangladesh-s-cultural-heritage-1.702303|title=Dhaka Art Summit lauds Bangladesh’s cultural heritage|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saatsaatharts.org/dhaka-art-summit-2016|title=SAAT SAATH ARTS|website=www.saatsaatharts.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gulfnews.com/culture/arts/300-artists-10-exhibitions-at-dhaka-art-summit-1.2166088#.WnMO1lTH-wI.hotmail|title=300 artists, 10 exhibitions at Dhaka Art Summit|first=Nilima PathakSpecial to Weekend|last=Review|date=31 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ocula.com/magazine/reports/into-the-blue--dhaka-art-summit-2018/|title=Into the Blue: Dhaka Art Summit 2018 - Ocula|date=14 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/foreign-affairs/2018/02/04/swiss-president-dhaka/|title=Swiss President Alain Berset in Dhaka|date=4 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
== Contribution ==
Nadia Samdani is a member of [[Tate]]'s South Asia Acquisitions Committee, Tate's International Council, [[Art Dubai]]'s Advisory Council, [[Alserkal Avenue]]'s Programming Committee, Parasol Unit's International Committee and is one of the founding members of [[Harvard University]]'s Lakshmi Mittal South Asia Institute's Arts Advisory Council. She is also the Vice- President of [[Alliance Française]] de Dhaka.<ref name="dhakacourier.com.bd">{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakacourier.com.bd/rajeeb-and-nadia-samdani-among-top-art-collectors-in-the-world/|title=Rajeeb and Nadia Samdani among top art collectors in the world|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/committees/|title=Committees - Art Dubai|first=Art|last=Dubai|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abudhabicityinfo.com/news/pr_Alserkal_Avenue_Announces_New_Homegrown_Programme_Featuring.aspx|title=Alserkal Avenue Announces New Homegrown Programme Featuring Premieres During Dubai Art Week 2015 - Abu Dhabi Press Releases, News, Events, Metro, Immigration, Visas, Travel, Tourism, Sports, Education, Jobs, Employment, City Talk, Real Estate, Properties & more|website=www.abudhabicityinfo.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mittalsouthasiainstitute.harvard.edu/2015/12/sai-forms-arts-advisory-council/|title=Founding members form South Asian Arts Council • Lakshmi Mittal South Asia Institute|date=9 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.afdhaka.org/executive_committee_and_constitution.php|title=Executive Committee & Constitution|website=www.afdhaka.org}}</ref>
Nadia has contributed numerous articles about the role of the collector and arts patron within the international art scene for publications including, [[Art Asia Pacific]], and leading business and financial daily ''[[Live Mint]]''. She has spoken about collecting at many international art fairs and universities, including: the [[University of California]], [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]]; [[Art Basel]] Hong Kong; [[Frieze Art Fair]], London; the [[India Art Fair]]; and the 2nd edition of the Private Museum Conference. In 2017, Nadia also contributed to [[UNESCO]]'s Global Report on Monitoring the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artasiapacific.com/Magazine/Almanac2013|title=ArtAsiaPacific: Almanac2013|website=artasiapacific.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/9xY5KUtETFmE4TPKqhaj4L/Collecting-Art-Is-Deeply-Personal.html|title=Collecting Art Is Deeply Personal|first=Nadia|last=Samdani|date=22 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dk1ArswjsxM|title=South Asian Art: A Conversation between Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani and Chitra Ganesh|first=|last=Institute for South Asia Studies UC Berkeley|date=3 May 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artbasel.com/events/detail/6697/Artworld-Talk-The-Art-of-the-Commission-Funding-Cultural-Production|title=Artworld Talk - The Art of the Commission: Funding Cultural Production - Events - Art Basel|first=Art|last=Basel|website=Art Basel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-268590|title=Nadia Samdani participates in Speaker's Forum, India Art Fair|date=11 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.larryslist.com/artmarket/features/highlights-from-the-second-edition-of-the-private-museum-conference/|title=Highlights from the Second Edition of the Private Museum Conference|website=www.larryslist.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/sseas.html?event_ID=116608&date=2018-04-27|title=South Asian Art - Past, Present, Future|website=events.berkeley.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.unesco.org/creativity/sites/creativity/files/concept_note_global_report_2017_0.pdf |title=Report |website=en.unesco.org |format=PDF}}</ref>
== Art collection == Nadia Samdani is a second generation art collector and began her own collection at the age of 22. She collects both Bangladeshi and international art. Nadia and her husband Rajeeb Samdani's collection includes over 2000 modern and contemporary artworks. South Asian and diaspora collection highlights include works by: Anish Kapoor; Gaganendranath Tagore; Abanindranath Tagore; Rabindranath Tagore; Huma Bhabha; Naeem Mohaiemen; Rana Begum; Raqs Media Collective; Shilpa Gupta; Shahzia Sikander; Novera Ahmed; and Zarina Hashmi, etc. International collection highlights include works by: Lynda Benglis; Chris Ofili; Alighiero Boetti; Paul Klee; Ettore Spalletti; Cindy Sherman; Marina Abramovic; Ai Weiwei; Pawel Althamer; Mona Hatoum; Philippe Parreno; Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster; Cardiff and Miller; and Anthony McCall.<ref name="dhakacourier.com.bd"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://museumnetwork.sothebys.com/article/breaking-new-ground-for-contemporary-art-in-bangladesh|title=Breaking New Ground for Contemporary Art in Bangladesh|date=6 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/our-collection/|title=OUR COLLECTION|website=Samdani Art Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/nadia-and-rajeeb-samdani/|title=Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani -|website=ARTnews}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://independent-collectors.com/interviews/nadia-rajeeb-samdani-dhaka-art-summit/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani - Independent Collectors|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.in/content/samdani-residence-art/|title=In the fairytale home of the Samdanis, the art is the hero|website=Architectural Design - Interior Design - Home Decoration Magazine - AD India}}</ref>
Artworks from their collection have travelled to major exhibitions, such as: Documenta14 (2017); Shanghai Biennale (2017); Office for Contemporary Art, Norway (2016); Centre Pompidou, Paris (2015); Kunstsammlung Nordhrhein, Düsseldorf (2016); Gwangju Biennale, South Korea (2014); and the Kochi-Muziris Biennale, India (2014), etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.documenta14.de/en/artists/13547/lala-rukh|title=Lala Rukh|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oca.no/programme/notations/the-missing-one.1|title=The Missing One: Programme: OCA|first=Dorian|last=Moore|website=www.oca.no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=29. 9. 2015 |url=https://www.spikeartmagazine.com/en/image-article/dominique-gonzalez-foerster-1887-2058-centre-pompidou |title=Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster, 1887-2058 @ Centre Pompidou |publisher=Spike Art Magazine |date= |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kunstsammlung.de/en/discover/exhibition-archive/2016.html|title=Kunstsammlung NRW: 2016|first=internetagentur bonn köln sunzinet typo3 und reddot|last=programmmierung|website=www.kunstsammlung.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/blog/2017/4/18/huma-muljis-work-at-gwangju-biennale|title=SAF AROUND THE WORLD: HUMA MULJI'S LOST AND FOUND AT GWANGJU BIENNALE|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="kochimuzirisbiennale.org">{{cite web|url=http://kochimuzirisbiennale.org/project-support/|title=Project Support - Kochi-Muziris Biennale 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
== Personal life ==
Nadia is married to Rajeeb Samdani who is the Managing Director of Golden Harvest Group, Co-Founder and Trustee of the Samdani Art Foundation and Dhaka Art Summit, and Chairman of Gulf International Finance Limited, UAE. They have three daughters: Radyna, Alvina and Maya. The couple is well known for their local and international art collection as well as their art philanthropy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hellopakistanmag.com/hello-pakistan/the-creatives-behind-dhaka-art-summit/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani: The Creatives Behind Dhaka Art Summit -|date=3 June 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
== Acknowledgement ==
Nadia and her husband Rajeeb have received several awards for their philanthropy. They were the first South Asians to receive the Montblanc de la Culture Arts Patronage award in 2017. They have also been recognised in Artnews's Top 200 Collectors list in 2015, 2016 and 2017, in ArtReview's Power 100 list in 2015, 2016 and 2017, and in ArtNet News's World's Top 100 Art Collectors in 2016. In 2018, Nadia received a "Recognition of Merit" award in the category of outstanding entrepreneur and innovator from the Rotary Club of Dhaka North during their celebration of 50 Golden Years. She has also received recognition as the "Most Inspiring Female in Promoting Art" at the 2018 Women in Leadership Fest in Dhaka.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.harpersbazaararabia.com/art/news/montblanc-de-la-culture-arts-patronage-award-presented-in-dubai|title=Montblanc De La Culture Arts Patronage Award Presented In Dubai|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200year/2015/|title=2015 Archives|website=ARTnews}}</ref><ref name="artreview1">{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/power_100/nadia_rajeeb_samdani/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani / Power 100 / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/market/worlds-top-100-art-collectors-part-two-513953|title=The artnet News Index: The World's Top 100 Art Collectors for 2016, Part Two - artnet News|date=15 June 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/power_100/|title=Power 100 / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref name="artreview1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theindependentbd.com/arcprint/details/145504/2018-04-12 |title=Rotary Club marks golden jubilee |publisher=theindependentbd.com |date=12 April 2018 |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/dhaka/2018/03/11/wil-fest-2018-celebrates-inspiring-women/|title=WIL Fest 2018 celebrates inspiring women|date=10 March 2018|publisher=}}</ref> {{clear}}

Geography at the [[University of Exeter]].{{cite web|title=Refugee crisis: Is climate change affecting mass migration?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/refugee-crisis-is-climate-change-affecting-mass-migration-10490434.html|website=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=3 March 2016}} He was educated at Adger|url=http://geography.exeter.ac.uk/staff/index.php?web_id=Neil_Adger|website=[[University of Exeter]]|accessdate=3 March 2016}} He was awarded a [[Philip Leverhulme Prize]] in 2001 and is a
